I8b4 araṇā-vyihārai biśä-pīrmāttama ‘being in strifelessness, of all foremost’; ibid. 19a1 araṇä cu samāhāña āṇadai ‘who without strife dwells in a trance’ (BS samādhāna-). See ānandaa-, s.v. āh- ‘sit’.

[DKS] ‘come’, participle, masc. sing. ātä, later ā above, fem. sing, āta (Ⅱ 89.48 hīna āta ‘the troop came’), masc. plur. K 137.914-15 cī vara āta himya tti... sādhukārä hauḍāmdä ‘when they had come, they uttered the (words) good, good’; Ⅱ 96-94 mara vā ttūśā āvä ‘here they came empty’; Ⅱ 126.19 hvaṇḍä āva ‘men came’; 1 sing, v 381, 3v4 ātūmä, N 332, 24v5 ātumä ‘I came’, BS G 37, 21b6 anuprāpta-ḥ, Ⅳ 25.7.9 hāysa ātum ‘I have come far’; Ⅱ 68, 143a6-7 khu vā birgaṃdara āṃna ātū ‘I have come from Birgarṃdara’. In a document āva is for ‘amount to’, Ⅱ 110.13-14 dvī pveca u śā jsā vā heysda āva ‘they have at present amounted to two coverings and also one’: ibid. 19 pātca vā pvaica āva dvī heysde ‘then the coverings have amounted at present to two ’; ibid. 27 āśī hīye vā pveca āva drraye ‘ the coverings of the āṛya-monk amount to three’; ibid. 29-30 pātca vā āśī, hīya pveca āva śā. From *āgata-, base gam-:gata-, Av. gata-, γəmata-, Zor.P. āmat ﹤*ā-gmata-, IE Pok. 464-5 gụem-, O.Ind. gam-:gata-, Greek βαίυω, βατós. See pa,jsama-, naljsam-, hajsam-.
[DKS] ‘overflowing’, Z 292.16 dukhinai ttīyä bäśśä ātajsandä tcei,mañi ‘all eyes overflowing then through grief for him’. Base tak- ‘flow’, see cognates s.v. tajs-.

[DKS] āṇa- ‘a missile weapon’, Z 4.60 ttṛśśūla kāḍare hãlśtä, bādāra ātaṇa u cakra ‘tridents, swords, spears, lances (?), slings (?) and discus’. BS lists show tomara- ‘lance’ which may be bādāra as ‘thrusting weapon’, and bhiṇḍipāla- ‘missile weapon, sling or dart’; Tokhara A has bhiṇḍipāl, Uigur bintipal. From *ā-šana- ‘missile’, to šan- ‘ to throw down, shake down ’, Sogd. šn- ‘to shake’, BS kamp-. See cognates s.v. sāñīndi, =BS patanti. For ‘sling’, note Av. fradaxśanā- ‘sling’, with daxś- ‘throw’, see dīś- ‘throw’, Zor.P. kōpēn from *kaupanya-. For the form note Av. ákana- ‘quiver’, base kan- ‘cover’.

[DKS] āgama- ‘desire’, plural SuvO. 54v3 mamä ttätä ātama sambajāṃdu, BS sarve cābhiprāyāḥ samṛdhyantu ‘may all my desires be fulfilled’; Z 2.194 āgamu; SudP. 72v1 āvama, BS abhiprāya--, gen. plur. K 90.740 harbiśāṃ ātamāṃ haṃberākä ‘fulfiller of all desires’; K62, 76v4 āva; plur. Manj. 136 āauvama; inst. sing. Ⅲ 129.11 āvaṃni; plur. Ⅲ 137.19 āvama; JS 38v2 āvaṃ. v 64.42 ttyi hvaṃḍi ātaṃ haṃbirūṃ ‘I will fulfil the man’s desire’; loc. sing. Ⅱ 106.131 pacā āśaryāṃ āyīma ‘in desire for the five teachers’, BS pancaka- ‘group of five’. Verbal ātīm-, base ā-kam-.
[DKS] ‘they fall into’, Z 24.168 kye vā pāstuṃgga ātasāre ‘some fall headlong’. Base kas- ‘to fall’, see uskasāte, kaśś-.

[DKS] ‘to desire’, pres. I plur. Ⅲ 128.2 āyīmāmane; 3 plur. V 122, 1v1 ātīmāre; participle Bcd 54v2 āyimānai āna, BS anuprārthayamāna-', SuvO. 54r3 ātīmānä, BS -kāmena; pret. 3 plur. K 143, 1057 hvanau ātaudāndä u ysustāṃdī ‘they desired the preaching and approved it’, = BS bhāṣitam abhyanandan, Tib. gzuŋs-pa-la mŋon-par bstod-do', later auda-, Ⅲ 72-166 ātaṃ aude ‘he desired a desire’. Base ā-kam-, to Av. kā-, kāma-, čakana, O.Ind. kāyamāna-, kāma-, kamiṣyate, cakamāna-; beside kan-, see ācastai ‘ you desired ’ above; Waxī kəmī-, kami-: kəmətt, kamat ‘will; agree’, Sanglēčī kəmay-.

[DKS] ‘to desire’, pres. I plur. Ⅲ 128.2 āyīmāmane; 3 plur. V 122, 1v1 ātīmāre; participle Bcd 54v2 āyimānai āna, BS anuprārthayamāna-', SuvO. 54r3 ātīmānä, BS -kāmena; pret. 3 plur. K 143, 1057 hvanau ātaudāndä u ysustāṃdī ‘they desired the preaching and approved it’, = BS bhāṣitam abhyanandan, Tib. gzuŋs-pa-la mŋon-par bstod-do', later auda-, Ⅲ 72-166 ātaṃ aude ‘he desired a desire’. Base ā-kam-, to Av. kā-, kāma-, čakana, O.Ind. kāyamāna-, kāma-, kamiṣyate, cakamāna-; beside kan-, see ācastai ‘ you desired ’ above; Waxī kəmī-, kami-: kəmətt, kamat ‘will; agree’, Sanglēčī kəmay-.
[DKS] ‘he may dwell’, Z 2-222 ka vā vara dāḍaru ā'te' lakṣaṇyo āysäte balysi‘ if he may dwell there longer, the Buddha adorned with the marks’, to āh- ‘sit, dwell, stay’, with 3 plur. ā're.

[DKS] ‘refraining from’, K 57, 23v3 ba’ysūñavuysai jsaṃjä jsa ātsāna yaṃdi ‘the bodhisattva refrains from killing’, the śikṣāpada- 1 prāṇātipāta-viratiḥ, Pali pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, see BSOAS 13, 1950, 662. Base čyā-, see bitsāṃgya, and tsāṣṭa-.

[DKS] ‘prince’, variant to raudäka-, Ⅲ 39-72 (examples of amorous passion) rauste a<bi>ñe pajsi ṣi’ ādrrakä rāma ṣai 28 ‘prince Rāma even he lost the five magic powers’, = Ⅲ 43.25 raustaṃ abai’ña pajsa ṣa’ raudäkä rauma ṣe’ ‘ even prince Rāma lost the five magic powers’. The -ka- is diminutive suffix, here toādrra- and rauda-:rrund-‘king’, nom. sing, rre, gen. sing, rrundä. The άπαξ ādrra- is from older āndra-, from ā with the base nar-: nr- ‘be skilled, able, virile’, hence *ānra- › * āndra- by the frequent intrusion of the dental stop -d- between -nr-. The word is formed like Lahndā āṇḍrā, Kalāşa ōṇḍrak ‘egg’ from *ā-nra-ka- of the base nar-: nr- ‘to swell’, in Oss. D. närsun, I.närsyn, närst ‘to swell’, DI.nard ‘fat’ (adj. and noun); Vedic āṇḍá-, later aṇḍa-. See also āṃdi’.
[DKS] ‘being in’, whence ‘from’, Ⅲ 61-53; v 246, 13aI ona, elsewhere aunaka. From the participle āna- to āh-.
[DKS] particle after cu, v 5.7.2 ttye pracaina cu āna; v 3.1 ttye pra<cai>na cu āṃ ‘because’; v 5.6397, 2.2 ttye pracaina cu āna.

[DKS] Sid. I02v2 read ā na ‘not’ (ā = āṃ), Tib. mi ‘not’.
[SVK] This interpretation is contradicted by Bailey’s interpretation of this passage in Dict. s.v. pähad-, where he has: ‘Sid. 102v2 vī ā (vīnā?) pyihasti ą̄na padajsāñä “without cutting to be burnt”, Tib. mi-bcad-par bsreg-go. ’
In this part of Si 13.35 the Tibetan has hbrum-bu mćhon-gyis bead-la / hphro lcags-kyis bsreg-go // yaṅ-na mi-bcad-par bsreg-go // ‘he must cut (chittvā) the pustules with a sharp instrument and burn (vahninā sādhayet) the remainder with (a hot) iron. Alternatively, he may burn it without cutting them.’ Thus, it is clear that na in the Khotanese cannot correspond to Tibetan mi ‘not’ because na padajsāñä could only mean ‘it is not to be burned’ whereas the Tibetan has the opposite.
The passage reads in the Khotanese version: ttai mą̄ṇḍaka nauṣṭarą jsa pyįhą̄ñä. u tvā pyihaca hīśinakä jsa padajsą̄ñä. ā vā-v-ī āpyihasti ą̄na *padajsą̄ñä (Si 13.35 102v2 KT 1.38) ‘those pustules must be cut off (chittvā) with a *sharp instrument, and the cut must be burned (vahninā sādhayet) with an iron (instrument). Or it must be burned by him while not having been cut.’
Thus, it is āpyihasti ą̄na ‘while not having been cut’ which corresponds to Tibetan mi-bcad-par ‘not having cut’, āpyihasti may be a miswriting for *apyihasti but it is just possible that a- has been secondarily lengthened as in āhvarai ‘sour’ (see Dict. s.v.). The emenda_x005f_x001f_tion of vī ā to vīnā suggested by Bailey would represent a serious change that cannot be supported, vīnā ‘without’ is elsewhere accompanied by a noun or a pronoun not by a past participle. The only occurrence of the word in Si is in A 8 (1 bis r4 KT 1.3) vinau mātsarä ‘without grudging’. [Emmerick, II, p.24 ]
[DKS] ‘ reddish (?), v 310, vii r3 vāra āṃna kabä ‘ excellent (?), reddish (?) horse’. If āṃna is from āṃṇa-, see āṃṇaka- ‘quail-like bird’ from *ā-raxšna- to rrāṣa- ‘red’.

[DKS] ‘protected, secure’, V 111, 33rI ānatu yanda, 2 plur. ‘you will protect’, BS ārakṣayiṣyatha*, v 108, 30r5 ānatä nu yanīyä, BS paripālanam kuryāt; Ⅲ 128, 29r5-6 ttäte haṣța gyastaṣṣā ttättu bodhisatvä ānatä yanīndä u haspījīmdī; Iledong 6, 2a 1 (unpublished) ne ānata tcera; later ānam, Ⅲ 50.42 karmapaha dasau maista ṣavi haḍā ānaṃ śtāka ‘the ten great karmapatha (BS karmapatha- ‘course of action’) must be assured by night and day’; Ⅲ 50.44 ttarandarä pathaṃka śtāka biśā’ ṣi’ ānaṃ tcere ‘ restraint of the body is necessary, the tongue is to be secured’. From ā-nata- to nā- :na- ‘to protect’, with second component nāta- (and ā shortened) or nata-; Tumšuq anāḏu, Kroraina anata, anati, anada, anadi, anada lekha, anadi lekha with the bases rakṣ- ‘keep’ and dhar- ‘hold’, for ‘carefully, sure’, see T. Burrow, The language of the kharoṣțhī documents 73. Base nā-, IE Pok. 754, O.Ind. nātha- ‘protector’, Greek όνίνημ ‘serve, be useful’. Possibly Sogd. ”z’t, if read ”n’t (KT vi 95) ‘exactly’.

[DKS] ‘moistened (?)’, III 84.53 na-ānahāṃ dvī prūyi maṃgārä gvīha’ rūṃ tcerai ‘it (a paiṇḍaka-poultice) must be made without moistening with two prūya-measures of butter (cow oil)’; III 92.237 u na-ānahā anarva māśa’kä tcerāṃ, ‘and it (the paiṇḍaka-) must be made with un­moistened unbroken māśa’ka-plant’. Possibly compound (with na- for an-) to base naf- (nap-, nabh-) ‘be moist’, Av. aiwi-nap- ‘pour upon’, napta- ‘moistened’, Zor.P. nam, namb ‘moist’, nambēt, nambītan (gloss to Av. haēk- ‘pour out’), naft, N.Pers. nam ‘moist’. To IE Pok. 315-16 enebh- ‘moist’, O.Ind. nábhas- ‘mist, sky’, Av. nabah-, ‘sky’, Greek vέφoς, νεφέλη ‘cloud’, O.Slav. nebes- ‘sky’, O.Sax. neҌal, O.Engl. nifol ‘mist’. Hence ā-nah- ‘to pour upon’, as Av. aiwi-nap-.

[DKS] ‘to be brought’, II 41.9 (SDTV 117) parau vā ānāñä ‘the command is to be brought’. From ā with base nay-: ny-, yielding ā-na- without trace of -y- (? naya- › na-), see also SuvP. 66v4 vauñāṃde, BS vāhayantu; III 38.32 hañāñāre ‘they are made to expand’; Ⅲ 72.162 nadāṃ ‘leaders (?)’; II 104.71 ganāyai ‘leader ( ?)’. Base nay-, Av. nay- with ava, upa, para, Zor.P. nītan, ānītan, nayišn; Sogd. nay- with ā-, fra-, pr”-, ti-; M.Pers.T. nyydn, pres. 3 sing, n‘yd, participle nyyd, riyd; Yidγa vǝnIm: vǝdëm ‘ bring ’ ‹ upa-nay-; Parāčī ēn-: ânt ‘ to bring ’, ūn-: ūnt ‘ lead down ’ ‹ ava-nay-; Kurd. ānīn. Zaza ān-. IE Pok. 760 Av. nayeiti, O.Ind. náyati, nītá-; Celt. Mid.Irish në, nīa ‘fighter, hero’ ‹ *neit-s, gen. sing nīath; Hittite nāi- ‘lead’.
[DKS] - ?-, v 262, DR oIa3 sa duva ānude haṣṭi brīti.

[DKS] ‘virility’, II 124.10 āṃdi’ va<-ṃ ?> ttāparya īḍeṃ (-eṃ = -ai, -e) ‘deign to act the man for me’. Assuming āṃdi’ from *āṃdra- to base ā-nar-:ā-nr- to nar ‘be virile’ (see also ādrraka- ‘prince’ from *ā-nra-ka-), as in O.Ind. Vedic āṇḍá- ‘egg; testicle’ *ā-nra-. For lost -r- from -ndr-, note also brya- › bra-, brra-, bryau ‘more’ › byo, brīka › bīka. The -ndr- › -drr- in ādrraka- has kept the -r-, but not the -n-. For nar- see also s.v. naḍe ‘man’.
[DKS] ‘disturbance’, Sid. 10rI ūysna āphārä ‘disturbance of breath’, BS śvāsa-, Tib. dbugs mi dbe-ba; Sid. 6v4 huña āphārä. Base ā with phar-, see pres, āphir-: āphida-.

[DKS] ‘disturbance’, L 89.3-5 karma vina dukhä vina abe’mañānu vina aysmya āphāranānä harbiśśu jyāre ‘the acts (karma) wholly disappear without woe, without ill- fortune, without disturbances in mind’. See āphir-

[DKS] ‘be disturbed’, Sid. 4rI beta vī bure paśä’ u pasālä āphirāre, BS kopaḥ śarad-vasanta-, Tib. rlung-rnams gčog- čing, ston dang dpyid dag dbyar hkhrug-par gyur-te; V 155, Ia6 ma thu rāhula aysmū āphirä ‘do not, Rāhula, disturb your mind’; Sid. 5r2 āphirīdä. Preterite and participle, Sid. 4r3 āphiḍa, Sid. 121vI āphiḍe, Tib. hkhrugs-te; Sid. 144vI äphaiḍä-, Ⅲ 84.40 ṣa’ śya’ had(ā) āpheḍe: Ⅲ 131, 2a3 anāphäḍa-, Sid. I06r5 ysaiysai āphīḍe, Ⅲ 84.44 ṣi’ ysaiysai āpheḍe ‘his bile is disturbed’. Causative, Sid. 5r2 tti maṃ bāta āphirāñāre ‘these here excite the wind’, Tib. rlung hkhrug-par hgyur-ro; noun āphirāme ‘disturbance’, Sid. 128v2 bāti āphirāme jsa ‘from disturbance of the wind’, BS kopatah, Tib. rlung hkhrugs-pa-las. See cognates s.v. phar-, pres. phir-.

[DKS] ‘to turn’, Z 24.500 trāmu ābeistä śśaṃdā samu kho ju cakṛ ‘the earth turns like a wheel’. See baḍ-, baltte, causat. baiś-, from *ā-vṛtsati.
[SGS] *ābei’ls- ‘to turn’ IV a mid. intr. B
3 sg. pres, mid., O.Kh.: ābeistä Z 24. 500. [p.9]

[DKS] ‘whirlpool’, Z 17.13 īse yande ku vā ābei’sa natä ‘makes whirlpools where are the deep whirling places’; inst. plur. JS 15r2 ābe’syau khvīyau vyaulasta bajāṣa ‘sounds horrific with whirlpools, waves’. See ābeistä ‘it turns’, without ā also Z 24.238 bei’sa, loc. sing. Z 24.412 bei’śśa, older v 40, v5 klaiśīnā bei’lsa ‘waves of affliction’.

[DKS] ‘total’, IV 3.14 lyiba’ āma ‘total’ dyadic, Tib. lib ‘all’; II 63.8 lyiba’ āma pajīdä ‘they demand the total’, without āma also II 21, 15a6 lyiba’ pajīdi. From ham-, hāma- ‘all’ without h-, beside hama- ‘all’, haṃgga- ‘total’ from *hamaka-, to M.Pers.T. hm’g, h’m’g, h’m- ‘all’, Zor.P. hamāk, Armen. lw hamak, N.Pers. hamah, Av. hama-. IE Pok. 902-5 sem.

[DKS] ‘we may be’, Z 5.107 ka tä muhu byāta ne āmaṃ ‘if we have not been remembered by you’. The older middle ending -āmane, is later frequently -āmaṃ, as IV 3v1 yanāmaṃ, IV 3v3 himāmaṃ, for older yināmane, himāmane.

[DKS] ‘dwelling-place’, acc. sing. SuvO. 54v4 ā’mato, BS vihāra- v381, 4a4 ai’metätu; loc. sing. K 1,134VI e’mäta ne biharāre ‘they do not dwell in the dwelling (BS vihar-), Tib. mi gnas-pa, V 140, 92v5 e’mäta; plural V 116, 65v4 dripäṣkala ju kṣīre ā’mate, BS trailokya-maṇḍale; later III 130b2 śira ā’ma byehūṃ ‘ I shall get a good dwelling’ ; Sid. 8r5 āme, JS 19r1 ā’me. From *āhāmatā- to āh- ‘sit, dwell’.
[DKS] ‘dwelling’, JS 13v3 himyai āmunä ‘you became a dwelling’, from ā with mān- ‘to stay, remain, dwell’. See also āmūha-.

[DKS] ‘short’, contrasting with dāra- ‘long’, V 299, 2r1 āmuro jsīno ‘short life’ ; V 297, Mac. a, b4 karma tcamäna hve’ amur<ä> ‘the act (karma) by which a man <gets> a short <life>’. From ā with mura- to Av. mūra- ‘defective’, mūraka- beside dahaka-. IE Pok. 751—3 mū-E5 in Khotan Saka muta ‘dumb’, O.Ind. mū́ka-, Celtic Ir. mut ‘short’, Lat. mutilus, mūtus, Greek μυκός, Norw. mua ‘be silent’.
[DKS] ‘dwelling’, V 286, 7r1 /// yaṃdi āmuhä; JS 15v4 bhāgä āmuhä nāsä ‘take portion, dwelling’; III 82.13 āmūha nāve ‘ took the dwelling ’. From ā with mān- ‘ to stay ’, see also āmunä.

[DKS] ‘possessing’, II 115.22 biśau bvaijsyā āmauna ‘possessed of all virtues’, parallel to II 115.21 biśau bvaijsyā haphau ‘union with all virtues’. From ā with mauna- from māna-, mān- ‘to stay’. But possibly ‘delightful’, if connected with mān- ‘delight’, see s.v. māja, to Oss. mondag ‘desire’.

[DKS] ‘to see’, Sid. 105r5 cvai hā śīyi śīyi hira āyiṃde u vajsyāte ṣi’ mīḍe ‘to whom appear bright white things, and he sees, he will die’, Tib. snaŋ-ŋ-čog dkar-por mthoŋ-ba ni hčhi-bar hgyur-ro; Z 4.100 samu kho purra āyäte ūca, Manj. 385 sa khu pūra āye uca ‘just as the moon appears in water’; Z 15.121 kho ūca banhya āyāre trāmä <. .>, Manj. 176 ā khu bahya chāyī uca ṣkaujai āyāre khu byave ‘or as a tree’s shadow in water the saṃskāra factors appear like lightning’; III 29, 41b3 ni jä nä āyāri hugvāna, Manj. 263 nai na ja āyāra hūgvāna ‘they do not appear at all’. Verbal noun III 61.52 ttyāṃ dharma-puṇyāṃ āyāme kiṇa ‘to see
those dharma merits’. Base ā-day- ‘to see’, Av. dai-: di-, see dai- ‘see’, also vūy-, pūy-, and āya ‘official title’.

[DKS] ‘official title, supervisor (?) ’, IV 26.7 ṣi’ pīḍakä pramāṃda hime khu hā āya haṃguṣṭe vistāte, ‘this letter becomes valid when the āya-official affixes his finger’, see SDTV 13 ; parallel II 14, 2b8-9 khuī parramā pyaysīdä ‘ when the parramaa- officials sign’. From ā-dayā- ‘supervisor (?)’, masc. ā-stem, to Av. daya- in paiti.daya- ‘overseer’, to dai- ‘to see’. If the final -a of āya stands for older -ä, the base would be ā-daya-.
[DKS] ‘mirror’, Manj. 246 vasve y(e) āya vīra satv(ā)na āvīda tcīre ‘in a clean mirror, one sees the faces of the beings’, parallel to BS ādarśa-maṇḍale supariśuddhe. See āyäna-‘mirror’.

[DKS] ‘it may be’, conjunctive 3 sing, to ah- ‘be’; 2 sing. Z 2.98 śśäru tsutai ma stātä āye ‘you have well come, do not stand’; 3 plur. Z 4.40 ku va yakṣa-bhavana ne āro ‘where goblin-dwellings do not exist’, BS yakṣa-bhavana-.

[DKS] ‘hilarity’, Z 12.75 ka bodhisatvä āyiḍetu näjsaṣḍe apracä, BS saṃcagghati saṃkrīḍate saṃkilikīlāyate auddhatyam dravaṃ prāviṣkaroti ‘if the bodhisattva shows hilarity without cause’. Base kar- ‘to play’, see cognates s.v. tcarke, and hayär-.

[DKS] ‘mirror’, Z 24.491 kye hva’ndi hūdva gva’ haysge patälste ttu mä na vā hvāñita āyärnna cu yīndi ‘what man’s two ears, nostrils (=nose) are cut off, you will not tell this to me what he does with a mirror’, =BS Siks. 47.5 saṃchinna-karṇa-nāsānām ādarśaiṣām kutaḥ priyaḥ, Tib. mi sna daŋ rna-ba bčad-pa-la meloŋ-gi či źig bya. Loc. sing. Z 4.100 āyäña, Z 15.123 ātīña, III 52.96 sa khu āyaña śāma ‘like a face in a mirror’, Manj. 283-4 uce pūra āyañe tcara ‘the moon in water, a face in a mirror’; Manj. 300 khu āyīñai dyāma tcīre ‘like the sight of a face in a mirror ’; Manj. 373 ā tcīra āyeña dette ‘as a face is seen in a mirror’. This is a cliché, as Mahāyāna-sūtrālaṃkāra 11.30 udaka-candra-bimba-sadṛśāḥ and Śikṣ. 261.18 ādarśa-maṇḍale. Without final -a- III 70.105 āyeṃ baña ‘bind on a mirror’ (Rāma’s advice to the monkey); K 28.181-2 khu ja āye spāśa ‘as a mirror appears’, =K 21.6-7. From *ādaina- or *ādayana-; Sogd. ’’δ’yn’k, M.Parth.T. ”dyng, Zor.P. aδvēnak, N.Pers. āēnah, Balōčī ādēnk, Oss. D. ajdänä, I. ajdän, to ā with dai-: di- ‘to see’.

[DKS] ‘example, simile’, Z 19.89 āyänai. Z 19.86 āyīnai, Z 19.91 āyīnau, III 74.201 āyanā vāśā’ṃdä yāṃdä ‘they continually recited examples’, =BS dṛṣṭānta, found in III 29, 44b2 diṣṭānta. From *ā-dayanaka-, see also āyäna-‘mirror’, to base dai- ‘to see’.

[DKS] ‘ground, sole of foot’, SuvO. 56r1 ttere jsa ttye dāta-hvāñei pānu ā’ye<. .>nīmä ‘with forehead I embrace the soles of the feet of this dharma-preacher ’, BS uttamāngena ca tasya dharma-bhāṇakasya bhikṣoḥ pāda-talau pratisaṃhariṣyāmi; SuvO. 56r3 odä vaśiriṃgye śśaṃdye ā’ye, BS yāvad vajramayaṃ pṛthivī-talam upādāya ‘as far as the ground of the adamantine earth’. See also eväte ‘street’, and aya ‘ground’. From āy- (the hook indicating older āyy-), with Av. āi, and N.Pers. xāk ‘dust’. M.Parth.T. ’y’g ‘place’ may be added here. For N.Pers. xāk a derivation from *āhaka- ‘ashes’ is proposed by G. Morgenstierne, NTS 12, 1942, 266, with Parāčī hāγ.

[DKS] K 156·17 for *āyaunye written possibly āyaunnye, lw from BS āyāneya-, ājāneya- ‘well-born’, III 64·20 āyānye bvaiysye jsīna (with n, not ñ) paba, K 156·17 ttravargye āyau*nye jsīña paba, II 103·52 bvaiysyai ttravargyai jsīña paba ‘three-divisioned well-born life continuum’. The adjective is also in JS 27V1 aśe yai āyānī rruṃde subhadrre ‘you were the horse well-born of king Subhadra’. BS ājāneya-, āyāneya-, Pali ājānīya-, ājāniya-, ājañña-, and compound assājāniya-, see JRAS 1955, 14. For -tty- replacing -ny- see V 64·43 ṣamattyau.

[DKS] ‘well-born’ from ‘born into’ the Great House
[SVK] In Bailey’s translation of P 3513 #82r3-4 KBT65 baiśa ysaṃtha daha ysyāne āysā krraña in Dict. 20b the substantive daha ‘male’ has been accidentally left untranslated. Preferable is his translation in ‘The profession of prince Tcūin-ttehi’, in Indological studies in honor of W. Norman Brown, New Haven 1962, 21: ‘May I be bom in every birth a man, well-born, showing gratitude’.
[Maggi, III, p. 23]

[DKS] ‘to deck, adorn, equip’
[SGS] ‘to equip; adorn’ III b mid. tr. B ppp. āysäta-
3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: āysindä Z 16. 60; āysändä Z 16. 62, 64.
3 pl. pres, mid., O.Kh.: āysänāre Z 3. 56.
3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: āysäte Z 2. 49.
3 pl. pf. tr., L.Kh.: āysyāmde P 3513. 72v4-73 r1 KT 1. 248. L.Kh. ppp. āysya- P 3513. 73r2 KT 1. 248 tr. samalaṃkṛta-.
O.Kh. inf.: āysäte Z 5. 96; 12. 17. [p.10]
[DKS] V 233, 496r1 (lacuna before Z 24·162) isolated word, āysīrä with yi

[DKS] later ār-, participle ārrda-, later ārda- ‘to grind’
[SGS] ‘to grind’ ? III b tr. ppp. ārda-
2 pl. imper., L.Kh.: ārryari MT a.i. 0033. 6 KT 2. 71; pt. nec., L.Kh.: ārrą̄ñä Si I50v5 KT 1. 96. [p.10]
[DKS] ‘fault, wrong act’, rendering BS aparādha-, āpatti-, doṣa-
[DKS] II 94·22, read āra vā hīśtą ‘fault comes to us’ = ‘we are at fault’
[DKS] ‘she told’, 3 sing. pret. fem. from auraṣṭa, participle to oras-

[DKS] ‘diminish’, see ārraje
[SGS] ‘to decrease’ IV a act. intr. B
3 sg. pres, act., L.Kh.: ārīśta Ch 00266. 318 KBT 109. [p.10]

[DKS] ‘to mix, participate’, participle ārsta-
[SGS] ‘to share’ mid. tr. ppp. ārsta-
1 sg. pres. mid., O.Kh.: ārīhe Or 9609. 3v6-7 KT 1. 232.
3 pl. opt., O.Kh.: āryāro Suv. K. 33v1 KT 5. 111. [p.11]

[DKS] ‘to move’, participle ārotta-
[SGS] ‘to move, shake’ V b intr. A ppp. ārotta-
3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: ārühäte Z 2. 103, 235.
3 pl. pf. intr. m., O.Kh.: ārautta H 142 NS 47 23v1 KT 5. 87.
O.Kh. ppp. ārotta- Z 2. 66; ārautta- Z 24. 224. [p.11]
[DKS] ‘excess’. From *ārda- by suffix -iyā- ‘state of ....’, to base -ar ‘to increase’

[DKS] ‘to sing’
[SGS] ‘to sing’ I b act. tr. intr. A/B
3 pl. pres, act., O.Kh.: āljsīndä Z 23. 159; āljsīndi Z 20. 7; 22. 266; 23. 156. [p.11]
[DKS] 2 plur. conj., III 75·230 ttai hvāṃdä sä khu da śūrä ā’va ‘they said to him, If you are a fine (da=dyena śirkä) hero...’ from either *ahāta or *āhāta, base ah- ‘be’ or āh- ‘sit, dwell’.
[DKS] ‘with straps (?)’. From ā with pas- ‘to fasten.’ See cognates s.v. pāsa

[DKS] ‘he sees, he is seen’
[SVK] ‘they appear’. Emmerick, I, p. 24

[DKS] ‘to bless’, later aun-, ān-, participle oräta-, later aurya-
[SGS] ‘to approve’ III b tr. ppp. oräta-
1 sg. pres., L.Kh.: aunū P 2026. 69 KT 3. 51.
O.Kh. pt. nec.: āvunāña- Z 4. 90.
3 pl. pf. tr., O.Kh.: orätāndi Z 22. 112; 23. 43; L.Kh.: auryāṃdä P 2958. 12 KBT 40.
[DKS] ‘filling’. From ā with pār-, par- ‘fill’ , but medial -v- may also derive from -v- and -b-
[DKS] ‘to gather’, participle āvasta-. From ā with vad- ‘to lead’. See cognates s.v. āvasta-
[DKS] ‘in a parable’. From *āvā- ‘something spoken’ , *ā-vāka-, to N. Pers. āvā(*ā-vāka-), Av. vāka-, fravāka-
[DKS] ‘surrounded’. From ā-var- ‘to surround, cover’, with the meaning of BS āvaraṇa, hence possibly a loanword from O. Ind. ā-vṛta-. See cognates s.v. baṭha-
[DKS] III 90·189 śiji āṣkä ‘a medicament, name of a plant’ in a list of plant names

[DKS] āṣṭan- ‘to begin, be about to’, Preterite āṣṭa-, āṣṭaṃda
[SGS] *āṣṭ- ‘to begin’ II b ppp. *āṣṭäta-
+ pres. pt. or inf., H. W. B., BSOAS, x. 3, 1941, 589.
L.Kh. ppp. āṣṭa- < *āṣṭäta-: 3 sg. pf. tr. m.: āṣṭi JS 26v3, 4 (117); 3 sg. pf. tr. f.: āṣṭā JS 17v2 (74). [p.12]

[DKS] ‘tread’
[SGS] ‘to tread’ I b or I c act. intr. B ppp. āspuḍa-
3 sg. pres, act., O.Kh.: āspīḍä Z 22. 147.
3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: āspuḍe Z 23. 153, 169. [p. 13]

[DKS] ‘sit, dwell, live’, pres. 3 sing. āste, 3 plur. ā’re
[SGS] ‘to sit; remain’ I a mid. intr. B ppp. āsta-
3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: äste Z 6. 18+.
3 sg. subj. mid., O.Kh. ā’te’ Z 2. 222.
3 pl. pres, mid., O.Kh.: ā’re Z 2. 45+.
3 sg. pf. intr. m., O.Kh.: āstä Z 2. 2+. [p.13]

[DKS] ‘reach(?)’ no context, possibly ā’h- from āfu̯- ‘reach’
[SVK] ‘he struck’. [Skjærvø, I, p. 25]

[DKS] ‘to restrain’, with -halj- only in āhaljaa- ‘restrained’
[SVK] ‘to control’. [Emmerick, I, p. 25]
[SGS] ‘to contract’ V e act. tr. A/B ppp. *āhrīya-
3 pl. pres, act., L.Kh.: aihai’jīda Or 8212 (162). b3 KT 2. 10.
L.Kh. ppp.: āhrrī Si 128v4 KT 1. 60; 132r3 KT 1. 66, v. H. W. B., AM, N.S. xi. 1, 1964, 24. [p.13]

[DKS] ‘to sweat’
[SGS] ‘to sweat’ IV a intr. ppp. āhusäta-
3 sg. pf. m.: āhusäte Z 2. 57. [p.13]

[DKS] ‘precious stone, prabably jade’
[SVK] Khotanese īra- corresponds both to Buddhist Sanskrit śilā and vajra as pointed out by Bailey. If the meaning was ‘diamond’ there is no discrepancy since śilā simply meant a hard stone. T. Burrow pointed out in The Adyar Library Bulletin, 44—45, 1982, 444—445 that Sanskrit hīra- means ‘diamond’ and that hīra- could be an Iranian loanword. He suggested that it may have been borrowed from a Saka dialect that had a prothetic h in this word.
The main river of Khotan is known as the Qara Qaš ‘Black Jade (River)’, a Turkish designation of the river that accords with the Chinese designation Wu-yü-ho (Black Jade River), which is known from the tenth century. The river is known in Sanskrit as Śailodā and in the Tibetan Annals of Khotan as śel-chu or śel-chab ‘jade river’. These matters were discussed in detail by G. Uray in Prolegomena to the sources on the history of pre-Islamic Central Asia, ed. J. Harmatta, Budapest 1979, 290—294.
Tibetan śel meant simply a valuable hard stone and so could be applied to jade just as well as to diamonds. It is no doubt a loanword from Skt śilā, although B.Laufer was uncertain (TP, 1916, 465).
Skt hīra(ka) meant ‘diamond’. It was explained as vajra-paryāya-nāma by Hemacandra, Abhidhana-cintāmaṇi 4.161. It is included as one of the fourteen names of the diamond in the Rājanighaṇṭu (R. Garbe, Die indischen Mineralien, Leipzig 1882, p. 80). In Mvy 5950 hīra(ka) is glossed by Tibetan pha-lam whereas in Mvy 5951 vajra is glossed by Tibetan rdo-rje, but the Chinese has 金剛chin kang (Mathews 1057 + 3268) for both hīraka and vajra. The Chinese is short for 金剛石 chin
kang shih (+ Mathews 5813), which really means ‘precious hard stone’. Tibetan pha-lam is explained by Jäschke as ‘diamond’, which accords with Sumatiratna’s gloss by Mongolian almas ‘diamond’. The latter word is well known in Iranian (Persian almās): see e.g. Bailey’s discussion of Pahlavi ’lm’s(t’) in his Zoroastrian problems in the ninth-century books, Oxford 1943 (repr. 1971), p. 134. The word is known in Russian almáz ‘diamond’ and elsewhere: see M.Vasmer, Russisches etymologisches Wörterbuch, vol. 1, Heidelberg 1953 s.v. Tibetan pha-lam is explained by Chos-kyi grags-pa, Brda-dag miṅ-ćhig gsal-ba, Peking 1957, as śel-rigs nor-buhi mchog ‘an excellent precious kind of śel’.
The above evidence makes it likely that Khotanese īra- meant precious hard stone like Sanskrit śilā and Tibetan śel. It could be applied to jade, the hard stone par excellence in Khotan, or to the diamond. Sanskrit hīra(ka) meant ‘diamond’ and may have been borrowed from Khotanese īra-.
The adjective īrīnaa- with the common adjective suffix -īnaa- is attested in Khotanese in īrīnā gari ‘the jade mountains’ (N 158.5). With a different suffix like the Khotanese adjective suffix -āña- the word is found in Tumshuqese xšere irāñye ‘of the jade land’ (= Khotanese *kṣīri īrīnai) in S. Konow, Ein neuer Saka-Dialekt, Berlin 1935, p. 41 (V. 2).[Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.29]

[DKS] ‘breath’
[SVK] The stem is uysanā-, not uysana- as revealed by the OKh. instr.-abl. sg. uysäñe jsa with -ä- due to trisyllabic weakening and with palatalisation of -n- > -ñ- caused by the unambiguous ā-declension instr.-abl. sg. ending -ie jsa.
To uysäñe jsa Bailey devotes a separate entry proposing the meaning ‘in one moment (?)’. The semantic development ‘in one breath’ > ‘in one moment’ is quite plausible, but a glance at the wider context where uysäñe jsa occurs suffices to show that it is to be understood in its literal meaning with E. Leumann, N 51 (‘Aushauchung, Pusten’): N 50.22-25 pātcu kāśyapa ko ju hve’ panamäta ce ttrāmo hoto näjsaṣḍe ku sumīru garu nāste nänerra tcabaljätä pärāñätä uysvāñätä o vā śiñe uysäñe jsa handarña lovadhato bīräta tta cu tä saittä kāśyava duṣkaru ṣä hve’ ttu kīru yīndä ‘Then, Kāśyapa, if a man should rise, who shows such strength that he would take Mount Sumeru in the palm of (his) hand, break up, scatter (and) throw (it) up, or (that) he would throw (it) into another world by one breath, thus - what does it seem to you, Kāśyapa - (is it) extraordinary (if) that man does that deed?’. I see no reason for regarding this passage as ‘parallel to K 60, 36v4 ttī hamye kṣaṇa uysānā ba’ysą dittä “then at the same moment the self sees the Buddha”’ occurring in a wholly different context. [Maggi, Ⅲ, p.28]

[DKS] ‘very’ in colour name
[SVK] Both ysīcaurga and ysīḍaurga are rendered ‘very yellow’ by Bailey (s. vv. ysīcaurga and ysīḍai respectively) whereas he renders śīyaurga as ‘white’ and haryāsaurga as ‘black’ (s. vv. śīyaurga and haryāsa- respectively). No reason for this discrepancy is given and no evidence is given for the meaning ‘very’. It looks, however, as though Bailey based the meaning ‘very’ on Si 24.19 (140r4 KT 1.78) since s. v. ysīḍai he writes ‘Sid. 140r4 ysīḍaurgä hame “becomes very yellow”, Tib. ser che-la’. However, ser che does not mean ‘very yellow’ even though the Khotanese translator appears to have misunderstood ser as ‘yellow’. ser is here the equivalent of bser ‘cold wind’. The Tibetan has dus thams-cad-du graṅ-źiṅ ser che-la skam-du mi-btub-pahi sar ‘in a place (deśe) which is cold (śītale) at all times (sarvatra), where there is much cold wind, and where one cannot keep dry (= sthirodake)’. ser che-la ‘where there is much cold wind’ is thus an elaboration of the foregoing. The Sanskrit does not mention yellowness and it is not expected in the context. The Khotanese rendering is based on a misinterpretation of the Tibetan and cannot be used to prove that ysīḍaurgä means ‘very yellow’, for which śin-tu ser-po would be expected in Tibetan.
In Si 22.4 (133v5-134rl KT 1.68) and 23.8 (136v3 KT 1.72) śīyaurga corresponds to Tibetan skya. The former passage does not occur in the Sanskrit but at 23.8 the Sanskrit has pāṇḍu-pīta. The Sanskrit pāṇḍu-pīta was taken as a single item by the Tibetan translators, who were followed by the Khotanese. The Tibetan skya regularly corresponds to Sanskrit pāṇḍu alone and like it means, according to Jäschke, ‘whitish gray, yellowish-white’. It will be no chance that the Tibetan has skya rather than dkar-ba ‘white’. In any case it is clear that skya is not ‘very white’.
In Si 24.4 (138v2 KT 1.76) it is not śīyaurga that corresponds to Tibetan skya and Sanskrit pāṇḍu but ysīcaurga from ysīca ‘yellow’.
It is possible to account for the use of both śīyaurga and ysīcaurga to render Tibetan skya ‘yellowish white’ only if we assume that -aurga has a modifying and not an intensifying effect. In other words, śīyaurga must mean ‘whitish’ and ysīcaurga ‘yellowish’ rather than ‘very white’ and ‘very yellow’.
In Si 14.4 (105r3 KT 1.42), however, śīyaurga ‘whitish’ does correspond toTibetan dkar ‘white’ and not to skya ‘yellowish white’. The Sanskrit has śvetābhaṃ and not ‘BS pīta-’ as Bailey, Dict. s. v. śīyaurga. It looks as though the Khotanese translator has taken śvetābhaṃ to mean ‘having a white appearance’ and therefore ‘whitish’ rather than ‘white’. Similarly, kṛṣṇābho in Si 14.2 is rendered by haryāsaurga ‘blackish’ (105rl KT 1.42) and not by haryāsa ‘black’.
-aurga may derive from *-a-varna-ka- ‘having something of the colour of’ with *varna- ‘colour’ (cf. Old Indian várṇa- ‘colour’).[Emmerick, I, p.28][Skjærvø , Ⅲ, p.37]

[DKS] ‘circle’
[SVK] No evidence is given in the Dict, for the meaning ‘circle’ and the evidence of Si 26.7 points to the meaning ‘line’. Bailey quotes part of Si 26.7 with the corresponding Tibetan, which he claims is ‘different’ but which he does not translate. In fact, the Khotanese and the Tibetan agree quite closely.
[Ⅱ,p.32]

[DKS] ‘title’
[SVK] ‘secretary’ (?) [cf. ka’rä ‘title’, Diet. 53-54]
In SDTV 1.4 Bailey renders this word as ‘offer’ in the combination ka ’rä varāysai ‘the offer of the gratuity,’ but in Dict. 53-54 he suggested "ka'rä-official,’ which is certainly correct. The expression ka'rä N.N. in the I.O.L. and Urumqi wood tablets (see Skjærvø, ‘Kings of Khotan’, pp. 273, 276) clearly contains the title and name of the scribe. Thus, ka’ra- is probably from *ka -1 + -(k)ara-, with the ka ’-, a kind of art or skill, which Emmerick Studies 2.34-35; see the passages discussed there derived from OIr. *kaiša- (Av. tkaēša-, etc.; see also on kṣī below). The particu­lar skill required here is apparently that of official scribe or secretary, obviously an important position.
Such a meaning would also fit Z 24241 iṣvastu cakr̥̣ṇa . kau ’ rraukyo haṃkhīysgyo ‘arrow-shooting, discus, *writing, reckoning, counting,’ where kau ’, rather than being instruction in discus throwing, is one of the secretarial arts like reckoning and counting (i.e., calculation, algebra). We may compare Suv [16.12], Skt. text, 175.6-7: lipi-samkhyā-gananā-su- śiksito babhūva, for which only the third item is preserved in the Khot. translation (Leumann, N., *99vl) [... ṣu]murjo1 ve husīyu *väte ‘He was well learned in [writing, reckoning, and] *counting.’
In the Rāma story, it would no doubt be in the prince’s interest to have writing skills in order to serve the brahmins, and the texts in Ch 0050a, b are a student’s writing exercises or drafts of letters.
In the Sudhanāvadāna, ke' may have taken on the concrete meaning of ‘written (letter).’
[Skjærvø, Ⅲ, p.39]
I do not consider that Skjservo has proved that ka'- means ‘writing’ rather than, more generally, ‘instruction’, even though the instruction may sometimes have included instruction in the art of writing. I doubt very much whether Naṇḍa the monkey in the Rāma story learnt to write rather than received general instruction. Skjærvø translates cakr̥ṇa kau' in Z24241 simply as ‘discus, *writing’, but cakrna is instr.-abl. sg., which is why in Studies 2.35 I suggested it meant ‘instruction in connection with the discus’. Moreover, if we follow Skjservo in seeing ka- in ka’ra-, it actually provides a better interpretation if we assume the meaning ‘instruction’ for ka-as the ka'ra- will then be an ‘instructor’, which accords very well with the word varāysai that accompanies ka'rä in Hedin 44 and 45 and which Skjærvø renders ‘director’ s.v. harays- below. Whether what was given in the Sudhanāvadāna was an oral message or a written one as Skjærvø suggests, there is no means of knowing.
On the Khotanese word for ‘to write’ see on pīr- below.
[Emmerick，Ⅲ, p.39]
[DKS] ‘excellent’ in derivatives, see kalai, kalye, kalyāk̮yim, kalā-tcyarai,kalyāsya, akalāśca,kalsta-.

[DKS] kaś-,kaś̮-‘fall, come into, fail’
[SGS] meaning: see below. V b mid. intr. B ppp. kaṣṭa-
3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: kaśtä Z 22. 320; 24. 451; kaśte Z 2. 111, 118; 10. 12; Ⅱ. 27; 24. 504.
3 pl. pres, mid., O.Kh.: kaśśāre Z 10. Ⅱ; Ⅱ. 17, 31, 33, 47.
ppp. akaṣṭa P 3513. 48v2-3 KT 1. 225 tr. asakta-. kaṣṭe Z 24. 178 could be 3 sg. pf. tr. m. ‘attached’; kaṣṭa Z 23. 36. 3 sg. pf. intr. f. ‘was attached’. But ttye vī kaṣṭa P 2025. 156 KBT 16 = ttya vī kaṣṭa Ch 00266. 97 KBT 24 = ttye vī ā 2957. 49 KBT 33.
Et. kaśś- ‹ *kas-ya-, cf. ātas-. That kas- is inch. ‹ *kaf- as implied by H. W. B., TPS, 1945, 30 seems unlikely as *kafs- should result in *kaus- like ttaus- ‹ *tafs-. The statement that kaśś- is ‘inchoa¬tive of kas- ‹ *kaf-s-’ (Dresden, p. 471 s.v. kaś-) is meaningless to me. Three verbs may be hidden here according to H. W. B., AM, N.S. ii. 1, 1951, 31:
1. kaśte ‘falls’ Ch 00268. 47 KBT 103 etc., cf. Oss. D. xaun; Parth. kf-, kft.
2. kasta- ‘attached’ with *kaz-, cf. Arm. LW kazm ‘order, ornament’ (H. W. B., AM, N.S. i, 1949, 45).
3. kaśte ‘appears’ Z 2. 118 ‹ *kas-, cf. Oss. D. käsun ‘appear’. kaṣṭa- ‘attached’ could, however, be from a base *kas- and this has been found in Oss. D. nixäsun ‘to cling’ (H. W. B., JRAS, 1961, 54; KT 4. 90). Unless this is really ‘fall down upon’, we still lack an etymology for *kas- ‘fall’. In further support of a base *kaz-, H. W. B. has given me Sogd. h'z'kh ‘hut’, cf. NP kāz ‘den of wild beasts’, kāzah ‘house’ (W. B. Henning, TPS, 1945, 158, n.3)

[DKS] ‘planted, sown’
[SVK] Bailey quotes kälstä väta, Skt avaropita- from SuvO. 5v3 KT 1.234 [Suv 2.2] but does not indicate how kälstä väta is to be analysed. The compound tenses of the Khotanese verb have unfortunately never been discussed, SGS treating only simple tenses; however, they are very common and a few examples suffice to show how they are used. Past tense forms with the auxiliary väta- (pluperfect) are active or passive:
Active: SuvO. 5v4 [Suv 2.2] ce pajsamu yäde vätā ‘who had done honour’ (3 sg. m. trans.); [Suv 15.50] [byau]dāndä väta ‘they had ob_x005f_x005f_x005f_x001f_tained, Skt pratilabdhä babhūvuh (3 pl. m. trans.); [Suv 17.159] byūsta väta ‘(night) had turned into dawn’ (3 sg. f. intr.); [Suv 15.51] hämäte väte‘they had become’ (3 pl. f. intr.).
Passive: [Suv 16.46] *ci ... *āchyau skuta väta ‘who had been touched by illnesses’ (3 pl. m.).
We see that the active pluperfect is obtained by adding the proper forms of väta- to the simple perfect:yäde ‘he did’ — yäde vätä/e ‘he had done’, hämäte ‘they (f.) became’ — hämäte väte ‘they had become’. In the passive pluperfect we have an ordinary passive construction, the participle and the auxiliary both agreeing with the grammatical subject.
So we see that kälstä väta can be neither active ‘he had planted’ (kälste vätä/e) nor passive ‘they had been planted’(kälstä väta (m.), kälste väte (f.)). The Suv passage runs as follows: sā ... vätä yäda- vajsamä. kälstä väta ááärye härä bāta, Skt °krtädhikāro ’varopita-kuáala- mūlo. The Khotanese ought to mean ‘he was one who had done honour (to previous Buddhas); he had planted the roots of merit’. Since bāta is nominative singular one might assume that kälstä väta is simply a lapsus for kälstä väta. However, the problem is resolved by inspection of the manuscript. Indeed, the correct reading is not kälstä, but kälstai, and kälstai väta means ‘by him had been sown’, kälstai being from kälstä + i, enclitic personal pronoun 3 sg. Thus there is no grammatical irregularity in the text. [Skjsærvø, I, p.32]

[DKS] ‘a plant name’
[SVK] The plant name kulīrai occurs twice in the Si to translate Sanskrit arjaka ‘shrubby basil’ (Ocimum gratissimum Linn.): Si 2.24 (13v3 KT 1.20) and 22.11 (134vl KT 1.68).
Bailey’s Dict. leaves the ‘connexions unknown’. A glance at SiN 107 suffices to show that kulīrai represents Sanskrit kuṭheraka, which is there given as a synonym of arjaka.
See Die Sprache, 29, 1983.[Skjsærvø, I, p.32]

[DKS] ‘hole’,

[DKS] ‘hole’,
[SVK] N. Sims-Williams suggests that the Khotanese word is related to Buddhist Sogdian kwč'kh, Man. and Chr. qwč' ‘mouth’, which he derives from *kauždačī- + -ā-kä (BSOAS, XLVI.l, 1983, 47). [Emmerick, II, p.34]

[DKS] a particular art taught to a young prince, mentioned after cakrna ‘with discus weapon ’
[SVK] a particular art taught to a young prince (Diet.) Z 24.241 has:
huṣṣātä rraysgu harbiśśe sīye ṣṣahāne
iṣvastu cakṛṇa. kau' rraukyo haṃkhīysgyo,
which I rendered: ‘He grew up quickly. He learned all the virtues, arrow_x001F_shooting, discus-throwing, reckoning, counting.’ This rendering was based on conjectures made by Bailey concerning the words kau’ and rraukyo: see KT 6.53, 313. In KT 6.53 Bailey suggested that cakṛṇa kau’ may mean ‘casting the discus’ like Pali cakka-viddha-. In the Dict, he rather improbably takes cakṛṇa kau’ as two items ‘discus-throwing, slinging’, thus disregarding the instr.-abl. ending of cakṛṇa.
In the Khotanese Rāma story Narnia the monkey says: vilakä ṣṭāṃ sīyeṃ ka’brraṃmanāṃ pārśa’ yuḍeṃ (Rāma 141 KT 3.71), which Bailey translated: ‘While still young I learnt to think, I served the Brahmans’ (BSOAS, X.3,1941,567). In Dict. s.v. ka’ he quotes vilakä ṣṭāṃ sīyeṃ ka’ and renders it ‘when young I learned to think’. There he refers to N 176.5—6 ci ke’ sājīndä ggaraṇi-śāstra ci vātcu śākhe sājīndä, which he renders ‘some learn to think (= study) of the treatises of action (of the calendar?), some next learn the branches (BS śākhā- sectarian text?)’. Leumann had understood ke’ as coordinated with ggaraṇi-śāstra-. ‘die Prüfsteine ... (und) die Karaṇa-Lehrbücher’. His interpretation of ke’ as ‘Prüfsteine’ is presumably based on the assumption that it represents Sanskrit kaṣa ‘touchstone’. The interpretation of ke’ as an infinitive meaning ‘to think’ goes back to S. Konow, Saka Studies, Oslo 1932, p. 150 s.v. kāṣ. This interpretation is formally possible but it does not yield acceptable sense and sāj- ‘to learn’ is not otherwise construed with an infinitive.
It is also unlikely that the pupils are being ordered to think in the documents Ch 0050 a and Ch 0050 b in KT 1—3 ed.2 pp. 144—145, where we read (Ch 0050 b 2.2): parau hamye sa ka’ sājara ‘there was the order: “learn ka’ ”. The fact that sajara is written in Ch 0050a.6 and Ch 0050 b 1.3 instead of sājara should not discourage us from understanding this as sājara ‘learn’ as the repetitions show that the sentence is being practised by an unskilled scribe.
It is possible that the pupils are being ordered to learn ‘throwing’ but also not very likely. In the context it is also unlikely that the monkey Naṇḍa should have learned the art of throwing. Something more general seems to be required but something that could be associated with the discus as part of a royal education. This more general item is likely to be that found in Sudh A 69 KBT 34:pyari gyastä vīrāṣṭä ke’ hūḍi ysīrasthi, which Bailey, Dict. s.v. ke’ ‘message’, renders ‘to his father the deva-king he gave a heart-felt message’. Bailey proposes to explain ke’ as from *kaiša-, which he connects with Avestan t̠kaēša-. This etymology is formally without difficulty and provides the meaning required for all the passages under discussion. Avestan t̠kaëša- means ‘teaching, instruction’, which would very well suit what the monkey Naṇḍa learned when he served the brahmins and the prince would have needed instruction in connection with the discus.
Old Khotanese kau’ is probably contracted from *kätu’ for which cf. bätu’, acc. sg. ‹ *viša- ‘poison’. The Late Khotanese forms will reflect the old nom. *kei’, cf. LKh. ba’, be’ ‘poison’ for OKh. bei’.[Emmertick, II, p.34]

[DKS] ‘magician’
[SVK] Bailey derives LKh. kauvāle ‘from kaub- “to practise rites, pray”’ + *varda-ka- ‘practiser’. The difficulties of deriving Kh. °vālaa- from OIr. *vardaka- are already apparent from Bailey’s arguments, so that his etymology is no more convincing than his earlier one in BSOAS., XXIX.3, 1966, 520-521 (from Pkt. ‘*kāvva-vālaga-, keeper of the kāvva-, with -vālaga- as in Khot. mātṛvālai, BS devapālaka-’ and ‘*kāvva- from kāvya- [...]. It is, however, a conjecture to assume that kāvya- [“poetical composition”] had developed the further special meaning incantation’). Indeed, in view of OKh. mātṛ-vālaa- ‘priest of the mātṛkās’ and LKh. hasta-vālaa- ‘elephant-keeper’, it is better to look for the origin of LKh. kau-vālaa- in an Indian compound with °pālaka- in conformity with Bailey’s original suggestion. Since LKh. au may correspond not only to OKh. au, but also to ā, ū̆ or o, I have proposed in Studia Iranica, Meso- potamica et Anatolica, 1, 1994, 63-67, to see tentatively in LKh. kauvālaa- a continuation of an OKh. *kā-vālaa- to be traced back ultimately to Skt. *kāka-pālaka- with kāka- ‘crow’. With *kāka-pālaka- one can compare Skt. kāka-vānī- ‘crows* speech’, which occurs in Divyāvadāna 636.28 (ed. Cowell-Neil, Cambridge 1886) in a list of magic arts: kākavāṇī ca mantraṃ ca indrajālaṃ ca bhañjanī)[Emmerick, III, p.42]

[DKS] ‘country, kingdom’
[SVK] Bailey follows Leumann, Nordarisch 113 and E 414 in connecting ksīra- with Olnd. kṣétra- ‘field’ and points out that Tumshuqese xšera- prevents connection with Avestan xšaθriia-, an adjective derivative of xšaθra- ‘realm’. The latter connection was proposed by S. Konow, Saka Studies, Oslo 1932, 153 no doubt on semantic grounds.
Meantime N. Sims-Williams apud M. Boyce, “Mithra Khšathrapati and his brother Ahura”, Bulletin of the Asia Institute, N.S. 4 (In honor of Richard Nelson Frye: Aspects of Iranian Culture), 1990 [1992], fii. 7 on pp.7-8 has given evidence ‘for the existence of *χšaiθra- as a substandard variant of χšaθra- “realm” (whether as the result of contamination with *šaiθra- = Avestan šōiθra- “dwelling-place” or by restoration of the root form χšai-f and points out that *χšaiθra- provides a phonologically unobjectionable etymon for Khotanese ksīra- and Tumshuqese χšera- that is semantically more convincing than connection with Avestan šōiθra- ‘dwelling-place’.
[DKS] -?-, v 309-17, 1b2 ni gga lä u ni///; 2. u ni vara va///. Possibly BS gala- ‘throat’, see also Sid. 121V3 galā, BS gala-graha-.

[DKS] ‘bell’
[SVK] ‘bell’(Dict.83a)
Under this heading and elsewhere inDict. Bailey wholly or partially quotesKV53.0. The manuscript (Dumaqu 0021 #v4) has: kāmä ttätä dasau hāva ce balśa gei’tau’ bañätä. Bailey offers three partial inter-pretations (and three different readings for gei’tau’):
1. ‘what are these ten advantages for him who fastens bells on a caitya-shrine (Dict. 83 s.v. gätā’ka-； reading gä’tau’as inKT5.296); and ‘he [who] fastens bells on the caitya-monument’ (Dict. 90 s.v. gai’;readinggätau’);
2. ‘who makes bells ring at the shrine’ (Dict. 266 s.v. bañätäwith reference to ban- ‘to lament’ [seeDict.268 s.v.]; readinggä’tau’);
3. ‘he who makes bells in the shrine (rather ‘makes to sound’)’ (Dict.272 s.v. balsa-, readinggatau’；forban- ‘make, cause’ see Dict. 268 s.v.).
The first of Bailey’s interpretations is correct (cf.KV0.52 dasau hāva ce balśa kṣatru bañätä‘Ten are the advantages (for him) who fastens an umbrella to a stūpa’). Thisbañätäis thus nothing but the 3 sg. pres. act. of the common verb bañ- ‘to bind’ (seeDict.266 s.v.). The entry bañätä‘makes sound (?)’ can accordingly be deleted from Dict.
A similar passage (KV 0.53) is quoted by Bailey in Dict. 272 s.v. balsa-：‘kye balśuvo’ bañạ̈tä “who in shrines makes (bells (?))”’. In fact, the manuscript clearly haskye balśa go’ bañätä ‘who fastens a bell to a stūpa’. The acc. sg. go’ is contracted from gei’ tau’ (< *gätā’ku; -ei- is a variant spelling for -ä-, cf. Z 24645 jsei’ṇu vīrä and Z 1031jsäṇu vīri ‘in detail’). See also KVpp.93-95.
[Maggi,III, p.48]

[DKS] ‘faeces’
[SVK] ‘faeces’
‘Sid. 10v3kava hīvī gū"faeces of fish", BSśukti-"mother of pearl", Tib.ña phyi-saʼ(Bailey, Dict.).
Bailey's phyi-sa‘faeces’is a misreading of Tibetanphyis. Tibetanña-phyisis the regular rendering of Sanskrit śukti. It is guaranteed by the metre in such places as Vāgbhaṭa, Ah.，Sū. 6.53(Peking 29b7) and Rgyud-bźi 2T2048.phyis means ‘outside’and refers to the outer part or hard shell. Chos-kyi grags-pa, Brda-dagmiṅ-ćhiggsal-ba, Peking 1957, definesña-phyisaccordingly as mu-tig-giśun-pa‘shell of pearl’. In An illustrated Tibeto-Mongolian Materia medica of Ayurveda of ʼjam-dpal-rdo­-rje of Mongolia, ed. Lokesh Chandra, New Delhi 1971, 381 it is writtenña-phyiand illustrated. The Chinese gloss is石決明(Mathews 5813 + 1697 + 4534) ‘sea-ear Haliotis’, that is, abalone, a species of marine snail. Haliotis is literally‘sea-ear’and describes the appearance of the shell. In Vāgbhaṭa, Ah,Sū. 15.43 śukti is glossednakhaby Aruṇadatta and Hemādri. This nakhais in turn glossed ashasti-karṇa‘elephant ear’ by SoN p. 42 (405). nakhais identified by BhN 236 as the land snail Helix aspera. Hjam-dpal rdo-rje, loc. cit., explainsña-phyiasña-skyogs.skyogs is‘to turn’and is used of the same spiral shape. It is found in Tibetan words for the snail: skyogs-lto-hbu and hbu-skyogs.
Since in Khotanesegū is well attested as meaning ‘ear’ whereas gū‘faeces’ is not attested, it can be regarded as certain that the Khotanese translator did not, like Bailey, misread phyisas phyi-sabut renderedña-phyis as ‘ear of fish’.
It is likely that in Si 2.4 (10v3 KT 1.16) a plant was intended since this is a list (Sanskrit gaṇa or varga) of plants. It could be Euphorbia antiquorum Linn., which is said to have whorled branches and so could have given cause for being named after the spiral or ear-shaped appearan­ce of the snail .
[Emmerick, I, p.38]

[DKS] ‘foot soldier’
[SVK] Bailey posits the stems gūha-and gūhaa-with the meanings ‘harsh, rough or intolerant’ (Acta Asiatica, 23, 1972, 66), ‘foot soldier’, ‘brigand’ ‘brigand-like’ (Dict. ), ‘rough, ruffian’ (Culture 87), ‘savage’ (KT 7.79). These meanings require comment.
The stemgūha-, with the meaning ‘foot soldier’ assured by indirect bilingual evidence (Dict. ), occurs with certainty only inMañj138 KBT 119beśa aśya hastya gūha rahya tc‹ū›ra-ysanya hīna ‘the whole four-fold army (consisting of) cavalry, elephant troops, infantry and charioteers’. On the other hand,Mañj 332KBT130 has to be read ṣā’ mārīña ahna gū habaiśā [so Emmerick, not gūha baiśa as Bailey in KBTandDict. ]mārā hīna pūrāma ‘he has escaped from the noose of Māra, victory over the army of all Māras ...’ with gū ‹ OKh. *ggūtä 3 sg. pf. intr. masc. of ggūs- ‘to escape, be delivered’ (SGS 31).
Other occurrences of gūha(a)- given in Dict.are ‘III105-6.18-9 [= LSt9c-10a] aumācą skarba ttuka ca mara māja kṣīra ttu gūhau grūsīda “the harsh minister (BS amātya-), him whom they call here in our countrygūhaa- ‘brigand-like””, and Rāma 222KT 3.75 sūpī [[ra]]yāṃ gūhāṃ: kṣīra, interpreted by Bailey as follows: ‘in the land of the Supīya brigands’ (Dict. )', “‘in the land of the Supīya ruffians” (gūhaa- “rough”) probably intending bandits’ (Culture 87); ‘the land of the savage Sūpīya’ (KT 7.79).In other words, Bailey postulates a pejorative meaning ‘brigand’ from ‘foot-soldier’ in Dict. 89 and, conversely, an improbable semantic development ‘savage, harsh, rough, intolerant’ › ‘ruffian’ › ‘bandit, brigand, brigand-like’ › ‘foot soldier’ in Culture 87 and KT 7.79-80. However, the meanings other than ‘foot soldier’ are conjectured from the context ofLSt 10agūhau and of the Rāma passage, wheresūpī[[ra]]yām gūhām: kṣīracould merely mean ‘in the land of the Supīya foot soldiers’ or, still better, ‘in the land of the hiding places of the Supīyas’ (from gūhā-, since ‘Buddhist Skt.guhāmeans “hiding place” in general, not just “cave”’, Emmerick,Studies 2.37), which is a sufficient characterisation, from the Khotanese viewpoint, for the place where there is an āṣeṃjä ... maysairka (Rāma 222KT 3.75), a ‘terrifying pool’ (cf. Z 159māṃkuya rro īndä heinā khoca u huna ciṃgga supīya kye nä hvatäna-kṣīru bajottāndä ‘There are Māṃkuyas, Red Khocas and Hunas, Ciṃggas, Supīyas, who have harmed our Khotanese land’). Accordingly, the only certain meaning of gūha(a)- is ‘foot soldier’ (Mañj 138KBT 119) and the same meaning gives a suitable nickname for theagrakuleka aląkṣä aumācą ‘minister of a prominent family (but) without (noble) qualities’ (LSt9c), because, although ‘soldiers on foot, it seems, constituted at all times the bulk of an Indian army, [...] there was little glamour attached to them’ (H. Scharfe, The state in Indian tradition，Leiden 1989, 195).
[Maggi, III, p.51]

The following L.Kh. forms: gai’sāttā P 2786. 226 KT 2. 100;
gaisāttą̄ ibid. 220 = gaisāttā Or 8212. 186. a55 KT 2. 12; ge’sāttāP 2786. 233 KT 2. 100; gaisāttā ibid. 235, appear to be 3 sg. pf.tr. f., but the sense appears to require ‘he returned’. H. W. B. suggests contamination with āta-. Thus, gaisāttā < *ggei’sātä+ātäin O.Kh.
Et. Inch. < *gart-, v. ggaḍ-p. 27.

[DKS] ‘flour paste’
[SVK] It is not clear in Diet, what grauśe* is used to translate. Since in Si 21.34 (133rl KT 1.66) ādä ‘meal’ corresponds to Sanskrit saktubhiḥ and Tibetan phye, it will be āḍe jsa that corresponds to Sanskrit saktavaḥ in Si 22.12 (134v2 KT 1.70), not grauśe’. Si 22.12 mau jsa āḍe jsa grauśe’ padīmāñā ‘a paste must be made with liquor (madyena) (and) with (barley) meal (saktavaḥ. grauśe’ corresponds to Tibetan skyo-ma ‘pap, paste’. Sanskrit saktu is rendered by Tibetan phye ‘flour, meal’ in Si 3.31.8 10.22 21.34 and 25.8. Hence hol-kon, which Bailey could not trace, is likely to be the same as hol-skom, which is explained by Sumatiratna as phye-mar ‘flour oil’.
madyena saktavaḥ in Si 22.12 corresponds to madyaṃ ... piṣṭakṛtaṃ ... saktubhiḥ in Vāgbhaṭa, Ah, Ci.7.12—13, for which the Tibetan has phye chaṅ sbyar-ba (Peking 159al) ‘flour and liquor mixed’. Caraka, (7i.24.122 has similarly saktubhir yuktaṃ ... madyaṃ paiṣṭikamṃ[Emmerick,I,p.39]

[SGS] ‘to cause to digest’ V e tr.

Et. Caus. ‹ gvach- q.v.[p.32]

[DKS] ‘is convulsed’
[SVK] Si 21.2 (128v3—4 KT 1.60) cu be'ti jsa ākṣī'pakä nāma āchai cu yādą aga ne āhrrī idąu gvamą̄nīdeṃ is rendered by Bailey ‘what is the wind disease by name ākṣepaka-, (it is his) who is always unable to control his limbs and he is convulsed’.
Si 21.2 was discussed by me in detail in TPS, 1970 [1971], 115—120. Here in the Dict. s. v. gvamānideṃ Bailey has clearly accepted my rendering ‘one constantly cannot control the limbs’ (loc. cit. p. 118) whereas in Dict. s. v. āhalj- he offers the impossible translation ‘the limbs are not stiffened’, giving as the Sanskrit basis ‘BS stambha-" (which is irrelevant here as it belongs to 21.3) instead of ākṣepako muhuḥ-kṣepād.
gvamą̄nīdeṃ is explained by Bailey as being ‘from ava- and man¬ in Av. vaēmanāt̰". But which 3 sg. verbal form ends in -eṃ, let alone -īdeṃ' . Bailey makes no suggestion. If however the final anusvāra is regarded as unetymological, like that in the nearby īdą then -idę becomes a perfectly normal 3 plural present indicative active ending. Nor is it difficult to locate a plural subject. After the statement that ‘one constantly cannot control the limbs’ the expected consequence is ‘and they (= the limbs) convulse’. That is the rendering offered by me, op.cit. p. 118.
[Emmerick, I, p40]

[DKS] ‘distribute’
[SVK] The evidence for gvar- ‘distribute’ adduced by Bailey is confined to one passage in Sudh. The line in question is attested in the MSS as follows:
baiysūñe dyaume kaiṇa gujsabrrīyaCh 00266.49 KBT 22 ( = C) beysūñe dyaume kaiṇą, gvāḍai P 2025.88 KBT 14 ( = P)
biysūñi dyāme kaṇa gvāḍe. P 2896.6 KBT 12 ( = D)
According to Bailey the meaning of gvāḍai in P (= gvāḍe in D) is guaranteed by its correspondence with gujsabrrīya in C. He renders C by ‘for the bodhi-vision he strewed’ and P by ‘for the bodhi-vision he distributed’. By themselves these renderings do not make much sense. In his translation of Sudh in BSOAS, XXIX.3, 1966, 506 Bailey assigns the words beśa tta dāvīnā rana as object to gujsabrrīya and renders: ‘For the sake of bodhi-vision he scattered all these dharma-ratna.However, he does not explain what that could mean. His commentary on p. 515 is devoted entirely to the etymology of gvāḍai.
[Emmerick,II,p37]

[DKS] ‘to descend, send down’
[SVK] Earlier Bailey regarded gvahan- as meaning to ‘mount up’ as ‘opposed to vahaṃda “descended”’ [BSOAS, X. 3, 1940, 570, 593). Now he apparently regards gvahan- and vahan- as basically the same in meaning and also in etymology. In the case of gvahan- he gives the same explanation of °han- as found s. v. vahan- but he makes no comment on gva-. However, the three items immediately following gvahan- in the Diet, (gvahai‘ñä, gvahaiya, gvahaiśkye) are all assigned to *ava-xad-, which shows that Bailey regards gva- as a variant of va- from *ava-. At least that is what he seems to have decided by the time he reached p. 95. Earlier in the Dict., p. 90 s. v. guhei, two of the above words, namely, gvahai‘ñä and gvahaiya, are correctly derived from *vi-xad- . In the case of gvahai’ñä the derivation from an older gūhaiñä is made likely by the attestation of gūhaiñä in JS 13v2 (55). All the words mentioned so far beginning with gva- are Late Khotanese. gva- is merely a Late Khotanese development from gu-.
Thus, gvahan- is likely also to be Late Khotanese for *guhan-. Neither ‘mount up’ nor ‘descend’ is very plausible for a verb of motion with the preverb *vi-.
[Emmerick,I,p41]

[DKS] ‘yellow, green’
[SVK] gvā- 'yellow, green, as first component (Dict.)
gvā- is not ‘yellow, green’ from a base gau- but a Late Khotanese spelling of Old Khotanese ggūna- ‘colour’.
gvā-ysirūṃ āchai in Si 14.21 (107vl KT 1.46) corresponds to Tibetan nad Ijaṅ-gu kha ‘green-coloured disease’ and Sanskrit halīmaka, a disease associated with jaundice. On halīmaka see Meulenbeld pp. 312—313 and 627. Also in Si 14.21 we have aṃgāṃ hīya vī cha gvā-ysirų̄na hame ‘the complexion of the limbs becomes gvā-ysirų̄na' corresponding to Tibetan lus-kyi mdog Ijaṅ-gu khar hdug-pa ‘the colour of the body is green¬coloured’ and to Sanskrit harita-. The disease is called gvāṃ-ysirūṃ āchai halīmakä in Si 14.22 (107v4 KT 1.46), where the Tibetan has nad Ijaṅ-gu kha ‘green-coloured disease’.
Tibetan Ijaṅ-gu ‘green’ is used by itself to render Sanskrit harita- in Si 6.4, 8.5, and 17.3 and Khotanese ysarū is used by itself to render Skt. harita in the Sanskrit-Khotanese bilingual P5538b77 KT 3.124.
Since gvā(ṃ) is apparently superfluous Bailey has suggested that itmeans the same as ysirūṃ and explains it as belonging ‘to base gau-: gu- “yellow, green” ’. However, there is no other evidence that gvā(ṃ) means ‘yellow, green’.
[Emmerick,II,p38]

[DKS] ‘how many’
[SVK] ‘from  caṃ, canda-, Sid. 124v3 caṃ tcerai’ (Diet.)
caṃ tcerai in Si 19.27 (124v3 KT 1.54) is merely a mistake for *vricam tcerai ‘a cathartic (virecanam) must be administered’. The corresponding Tibetan has bkru-sman btaṅ-ṅo ‘a cathartic must be administered’. For Si 19.27 see s. v. pvāñā ‘to be smeared upon’.

[DKS] ‘oxalis corniculata, wood sorrel’
[SVK] cakurikā- is attested several times in Khotanese texts as the rendering of the Sanskrit plant name cāṅgerī, which has generally been identified as the wood sorrel Oxalis corniculata Linn. In Si 3.21.3 (17v3 KT 1.28) the derivative adjective cukurīkīji is found.
Among the synonyms of Sanskrit cāṅgerī is cukrikā (RājN 175 and 439 (41)). cukrikā is evidently a derivative of the *cukrá- ‘sour* implied, by Sanskrit cukra- ‘a sour juice’ and later Indian forms (see Mayrhofer s. v. cukráḥ; Turner, CDIAL 4850). cukrikā is listed in Vāgbhaṭa, Ah., Ci.7.31 as one of the five sour juices (pañcāmlako).
It is accordingly clear that cakurīkā- (adjective cukurīkīji) is a loanword from Sanskrit cukrikā and not, as Bailey tries to prove, a word of Iranian origin ‘from base čak- “be pointed, horned”, with suffixes čaku- with -ra-’. In a word of Iranian origin the regular development of Old Iranian *č- would be to tc- as in tcei’man- ‘eye’ from *čašman- (Avestan čašman-).
See Die Sprache, 29, 1983.[Emmerick,I,p43]

[DKS] ‘ for eye( ?) ’
[SVK] The word caksa has been noticed so far only in MT a.i.0044b3 KI 5.386: khvau tcimñāsta caksa parīhauda, which Bailey here renders ‘if he deigns to give caksa for our eyes’. In Saka documents text volume, London 1968, 78 Bailey commented that ‘The caksa are unknown, hardly from BS caksus- eye’, but in the Diet, he suggests that caksa is ‘possibly from BS caksus- as “eye-medicament”’.
It is clear from the context that caksa is a medicament that is inserted into the eye to effect a cure. Such a medicament is known from Si 26.22, where a prescription is given based on the powder from what is called in the Khotanese version (147v4 KT 1.92) cahä:sa. Khotanese cahä:sa renders Tibetan mig-sman caksu ‘the eye medicine caksu’. The Sanskrit original has äranya-kulattha ‘wild horse gram’. It is accordingly clear that caksu represents Sanskrit caksusyā (lit. ‘beneficial to the eye’), which is given in RājN 341 as a synonym of āranya-kulatthikā[Emmerick,II,p40]

[DKS] ‘plant name’
[SVK] No evidence is given for the assumption that cāmnä in Si 2.20 (13r2 KT 1.20) only is a plant name and not cq›nä ‘powder’, that is Sanskrit
cūrna, which occurs commonly in JP. In fact the context of Si 2.20 actually excludes the possibility that it could be a plant name, mauskakä bahyä si’ cu cqnä means ‘the muṣkaka tree, that (is its) powder’ and corresponds to muskaka- alone in the Sanskrit text. The construction is as in Si 2.15 (12r4 KT 1.18): sumana-sāriva si’cu symam hīya bāva ‘white Indian sarsaparilla, that (is), the root of the white (kind)’, which corresponds to śārivā alone in the Sanskrit original.
Note cqna'm JP [90] 115v2 KT 1.193 rendering Sanskrit cūrnam in Si 8.12. [e]Emmerick,I,p43]'beeswax'[not 'plant name'][Emmerick,III,p52]

[DKS] ‘plant name’
[SVK] No evidence is given for the assumption that cāṃṇä in Si 2.20 (13r2 KT 1.20) only is a plant name and not cą̄ṇä ‘powder’, that is Sanskrit cūrṇa, which occurs commonly in JP. In fact the context of Si 2.20 actually excludes the possibility that it could be a plant name, mauṣkakä bahyä ṣi’ cu cą̄ṇä means ‘the muṣkaka tree, that (is its) powder’ and corresponds to muṣkaka- alone in the Sanskrit text. The construction is as in Si 2.15 (12r4 KT 1.18): sumana-śāriva ṣi’cu sųmaṃ hīya bāva ‘white Indian sarsaparilla, that (is), the root of the white (kind)’, which corresponds tośārivā alone in the Sanskrit original.Note cą̄ṇä in JP [90] 115v2 KT 1.193 rendering Sanskrit cūrṇaṃ in Si 8.12. [Emmerick,II,p40]

[SVK] cāyūm is assumed by Bailey to mean ‘I consume’ and to be required in one passage only: JP [61] 99v2—3 KT 1.181. [DKS] ‘thick’
[SVK] ‘thick’
Bailey’s dara- ‘thick’ does not exist. It is based on a misinterpreta¬tion of two passages from the Si.
Si 26.55 (151v5—152r3 KT 1.98) describes a remedy for timira (an eye disease), which involves among other things slitting open a chebulic myrobalan (Sanskrit abhayā) to extract the stone and putting in its place a particular preparation. The slit or split made in the myroba¬lan must be covered over with dough before the myrobalan is put in a fire. This process is described in the Khotanese thus: darq hāmai jsa esalyāñä ‘the split must be smeared (digdha-) with dough’. That darq hāmai does not mean ‘thick pap, dough’ is confirmed by Si 26.57 (152r5 KT 1.98), where we find grihqjsa ttū kamalq darq, esalyāñä ‘the severed head (of the snake) must be smeared with clay’.
The second passage (Si 26.82 = 155v2—3 KT 1.102) is more difficult. Bailey renders darq ysirrā as ‘thick rough’ Diet. s. v. dara-, ‘thick, rough’ Diet. s. v. banaji, and ‘scraped rough’ Diet. s. v. ysira-. However, ‘thick’ and ‘scraped’ are quite different. The latter can be justified by reference to the verb dar- ‘to scrape’ and is in accord with dara- ‘split, severed’ in the passages discussed above. But the meaning ‘thick’ is based on this passage alone. Since the Tibetan version has here ril-gyis stug-po ‘wholly thick’ and not ‘rough’ whereas the Khotanese has ysirrä ‘rough’ it is unsafe to deduce that darq must mean ‘thick’ here only, darq ysirrä may just as well mean ‘cracked (and) rough’, cf. Sanskrit sphutitā used of the tongue disease due to wind in 26.80.
This dara- ‘split, severed’ is a Late Khotanese spelling of darra- ‘broken’: see below s, v. darra- ‘unbroken’! [Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.54]

[DKS] ‘unbroken’
[SVK] ‘unbroken’
Bailey claims that in Śgs 3.14r2 vysnora kye hamo darrä means ‘beings whose bowl is unbroken’ and not as in my edition (p. 47) ‘beings who have a broken vessel’. It is difficult, however, to see how darrahamau in Śgs 3.14vl could be construed so as to agree with balysūñavūysā hvañāre ‘they are called Bodhisattvas’. Moreover, since Late Khotanese has dara- in the sense of ‘split, severed’ (see s. v. dara- ‘thick’ ！), it is improbable that it should also have darra- ‘unbroken’.
It is dangerous to assume that darre in Z 20.43 should mean ‘held together’ (which Bailey appears to consider synonymous with ‘unbroken’) since more or less everything in these cemetery scenes is broken, torn, split, etc. What about nearby darra in Z 20.38, 39? In Z 20.39 darra is used of a thread that has been struck. Bailey renders this darra as ‘torn up’ (Dict. s. w. anāskotta, ṣṣonda), which is similar to my rendering ‘split asunder’. Indeed, wherever there is clear evidence it points to the meaning ‘broken’ rather than ‘unbroken’.
darra- ‘broken’ can be etymologised easily. It is from *dṛna- and can be compared with Old Indian dīrṇa-1 . Bailey’s darra- ‘unbroken’ on the other hand implies a participle *dṛna- that goes against both Avestan ddrdta- and Old Indian dhṛtá-.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]
[DKS] adjective to a place-name *darauysa-, v 209, ooIaI darauysāṃ ṣau khrrī dārrjai ‘the ṣau-official Khri dorjeof Darauysa’, to Tib.khri‘seat’, rdo-rj̆e ‘BS vajra-', hence for vajrāsana-.
[DKS] ‘ten’, K 43.Ⅰ36 daśā māśt(a) parsāme jsa ‘with the passing of ten months’, =K 40.18 daśau māśtāṃ jsa. See dasau ‘ten’.
[DKS] gen. plur. ‘ten’, 11 105*107 daśaina hāvām ‘of ten benefits’ = ibid. 111-2. See dasau ‘ten’.

[SVK] ‘section’ or ‘arrangement’ (Dict.)
In addition to dasa ‘thread’, Old Ind. daśā-, Bailey has the entry dasa ‘section’ or ‘arrangement’. This dasa is according to him found in two places, once in ApS and once in MPPS (the commentary on the Hṛdayasūtra).[Skjærvø, Ⅱ,p.57]

[DKS] loc. plur. ‘group’
[SVK] ‘loc. plur. ‘group’
dastakvā ‘group’ is based on an arbitrary interpretation of P 3510.3.1 [11] KBT 48. There ayīṣṭe dastakvā ‘I bless with (my) hands’ is closely parallel with dastakvā haudvyā ... ayaiṭha T bless with both hands’ in Deśanā 78r3 KBT 63. In both contexts the expression precedes the pūjā-karma (act of reverence) and in both contexts the object of the blessing is the Buddhas in the hair-pores.
dastaka in Z is confined to the hands in the añjali position (2.63 22.188).
See Stwlia iranica, 9.2, 1980, 189.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]
[DKS] first component, dā-gūna- ‘fire-coloured’, K 18.193-4 saramadā-gūna karavīnā bveya harrida ‘red, around, rays shine’
[DKS] see daurmīnai, from *durma-, Ⅱ60.17 dāṃrmīnai ṣkāma dale śau; Ⅱ77.23 daurmīnai bagala.

[DKS] ‘seen’ and ‘appearance’, for verbal forms see dai- ‘to see’;
[SVK] ‘seen’ and ‘appearance’ (Dict. 158b)
Bailey reads P 2928 #10 (LSt 4c) dya vī in KT 3.105 and quotes dya vī śairka in Dict. 150 s.v. da together with Ch 1.002la,a #33 KT 2.55 da śerka ‘fine in appearance’, JS 5r3 (16) di śirka, thus giving the impression of understanding dya vī as containing the postposition vī ‘in, at, on’ and meaning ‘in appearance’. The impression is confirmed by the fact that he again quotes dya vī śairka ‘good to look at’ in Dict. 165 s.v. dya beside Mañj 206 KBT 123 khu tterthyā dya vī ‘as in sight of the sectaries’, which is better translated ‘as in the (false) view of the heretics’. However, ‘in the (false) view’ is not the same as ‘in appearance’. A different interpretation is apparently hinted at in Dict. 158 s.v. däta-, where Bailey, after quoting P 3513 #72rl KT 1.248 (Suv [3.83]) 'dya-vīya “having a good appearance”, BS abhirūpa-' adds: ‘Also Ⅲ 105.10 dya-vī śairka'. Although Degener, Suffixe 309, correctly points out that most instances of LKh. -vī are not likely to be spellings of the OKh. suffix -vīya- and that dya-v-ī śairka in the passage under consideration could be translated ‘sein Aussehen war schön’, I prefer to follow Bailey’s hint and translate LSt 4cd daha' pūra dvyavī śairka | uspūryau aidrrā jsa khū *śakax1 as ‘a male child, good-looking, beautiful, with complete senses as Sakra’. In fact, an adjective dyavī ‘good-looking’ (from dya-vīya- ‹ OKh. *däta-vīya-) is more appropriate in the present context: it is the boy who is endowed uspūryau aidrrājsa ‘with complete senses’, not its appearance. Degener’s interpretation has possibly been influenced by Bailey’s provisional metrical arrangement that separates daha ’ pūra and dyavī śairka in two pādas.
1 For MS ścāka see below s.v.
[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.75]

[DKS] ‘so much’
[SVK] ‘so much’ (Dict. 158b)
Under this heading Bailey lists also ‘V 301, 27r2 dädä ku', without translation, from KV 15.3 dädä ku yä [ro aysmūjna yąnde ‘The third (act by which a man obtains birth in hell) is when one [also] performs (it = a great evil deed) with the mind’, Skt. tīvrampradusta-cittasya ... -mano- duścaritam. In fact, OKh. dädä can only mean ‘third’ (see Dict. 169 s.v. drai). [Maggi，Ⅲ，p.76]

[DKS] ‘stone’
[SVK] ‘stone’ (Diet. 158-159)
Under this heading Bailey has, among other instances of the word, ‘possibly II 41.10 dädä “stone for mounting (?)’”. The same interpretation is found in SDTV 1.115 and 117 ('dädä from *dädyä from dädäya-'). The sentence containing this dädä is Ch 0048 #10 KT2.41 padauysä aśä parauvā va pathāñä dädä spāśāña khu parauva-bara bvä'ttä ‘The first horse must be harnessed for the orders there (and) watched until the dispatch-rider mounts’. LKh. dädä khu means ‘so much that, until’ and dädä is just a variant spelling of LKh. daṃda- ‘so much’ (see Dict. 151 s.v. daṃda- and 158 s.v. dida-).
Cf. above s.v. dida-[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.76]

[SGS] ‘to tame’ V e tr. ppp. danda-
O.Kh. -āmatā abstract: dīmāmatā- Kha 1. 309a1. 43v4 KBT 9.
3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: dąnde Z 24. 273.
ppp., O.Kh.: danda- Zb. 20; L.Kh., daṃda- JS17r4 (73).
Et. ‹ *damaya-, cf. O.Ind. damáyati ‘overpowers’. Cf. H. W. B., KT 4. 163. *dam- is attested in Kh. in the -gyā abstract: daṃgyo Suv. K. 67r5 KT 5. 118 tr. damanaṃ; dagye ibid. 66r5 KT 5. 117 tr.damana-(v. H. W. B., JRAS, 1961, 55). O.Ir. *dam-, cf. Oss. D. domun ‘dompter’ (Benv., Oss., p. 90); Chor. δms- ‘be tamed’ (W. B. Henning, Togan Vol., p. 434)[p.45]

[DKS] ‘bad’
[SVK] ‘bad’ (Dict. 159a)
Bailey devotes the following entry to this ghostword:
‘V 301, 27r2 därä bäśāna yande “he acts with evil tongue”; ibid. 27r2-3 dä‹rä aysmū›na “with evil mind”; ibid. 27v3 ‘dasamä sä kyera dära u‹ysāne jsa?> “this is tenth, as much as with evil self’. Possibly dire in III, 9-10 dire vā anāspeti paśāñä yem “I have sent the bad, the refugeless ones”. See dara- “bad”. Possibly from adara- “inferior”’.
The first three examples are from KV 15.2, 15.3 and 15.10 respectively. The correct readings are: KV 15.2-3 u śätä ṣä ku yä ro bäśāna yande . dädä ku yä [ro aysmū]na yąnde ‘And the second is also when one performs (it, i.e. a great evil deed) with the tongue. The third is [also] when one performs (it) with the mind’, Skt. tīvram praduṣṭa-cittasya ...-vāṅ- mano-duścaritam (Lévi, KV 44.10); KV 15.10 u dasamä ṣä kye atärañ[ī näjsasde], Skt akr̥tajñatā (Lévi, KV 44.11). The fourth example (Balawaste 0154 #9 KT 3.131) is a Late Khotanese spelling for dīra- ‘weak’ (see Emmerick, Studies 1.55-56). See KV pp.108-109 and 110-111.[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.77]

[DKS] ‘bad’
[SVK] The meaning ‘bad’ is secondary, the primary meaning being ‘weak’. dīra- ‘weak’ is opposed to pata'jsa ‘powerful’ in Z 10.2, and it is used dyadically with duspäta ‘powerless’ in Z 24.270. Hence the derivation of dīra- ‹ *dirga ‹ *drigu- cf. Avestan drigu- ‘arm, bedürftig, schwach’, proposed by Henning in JRAS, 1944, 141 n. 7, should not be silently discarded. Moreover, dīramggāra- ‘evil-doing’ is a rare type of compound with inflection of the first member, which is matched exactly by Buddhist Sogdian SryiFnk'r'k. See on śśära- ‘good’ below.
See already JRAS, 1969, 65.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]
‘bad’ (Dict. 159)
The phrase dīrä (dīra) yan- act. ‘to cause to be ill’ (not recorded in Dict.) occurs three times in Ch. 00217a-c KT 3.135 (under the signature Stein 117.1-3).1 Its meaning is assured by both the context and the corresponding, though not parallel, Chinese text (‘this spirit is the cause of the trouble’, translation by A. Waley, A catalogue of paintings recovered from Tun-huang by Sir Aurel Stein, London 1931, pp. 171 -172) and lends support to the meaning ‘weak’ for dīra- and to its derivation from OIr. *drigu-, cf. Avestan drigu- ‘arm, bedürftig, schwach’ (see Emmerick, Studies 1.55-56).
Judging by OKh. śśäru yan- act. ‘to do good’ (Z 27+), LKh. -ä/-a in dīrä (dīra) yan- is from OKh. -u ‹ OIr. *-am. This is confirmed by the fact that the phrases dīrä (dīra) yan- and śśäru yan- correspond to the compounds Z 269 dīram-ggāra- ‘evil-doer’ and, respectively, Śgs2.4v2 śäram-gāra- ‘well-doer, friend’ with inflection of the first member (cf. Emmerick, Studies 1.55-56 and 1.117-118).
Note that a difference is made between dīrä (dīra) yan- with active verb and the frequent dīra kädagāne yan- ‘to do evil acts’ with middle verb (cf. Canevascini, ‘Medio-reflexive verbs in Khotanese’, in Mac¬Kenzie Fs. 23-26).
Cf. Studia Iraniea Mesopotamica et Anatolica, 1, 1994, 67-68. See also s.v. *dära- ‘bad’.
1 The phrase seems to occur also in the unclear sentence JP 47v2 KT 1.139 haṣṭav-ī dīra na īdä, on which see Emmerick, JEĀS, 2, 1992, 80.[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.77]

dīś- is derived by Bailey from ‘base dag-, with dag-ś-y- to diś-’ Bailey’s etymology was reported by me in SGS 46. Meantime E. Tichy has shown that dīś- derives from *daisaya- from IE *deik̑- ‘to throw’ attested also in Greek διϰεϊν ‘to throw’ (MSS, 38, 1979, 171—228).[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.56]

Sogd. ’nδyščy ‘Verwerfen’, d.i. pratikṣepa ST, ii. 575 s.v. From a base *dai- (with s-extension in Sogd.), the inch, should be *dĭs-. However, all presents of class V e in -śś have a long vowel in the root syllable.[p.46]

[DKS] ‘is put in’
[SVK] ‘is put in" (Dict.)
‘Sid. 15r3 jsä’ñāñä daṃda khu si’ *kaṣā’ (MS cuṣā’) dīṣḍa “to be boiled; so much this kaṣaya- decoction is to be poured in” ’ (Dict.).
Bailey proposes to see in dīṣḍa the 3 sg. pres. mid. form of an unattested present stem *dīṣṣ- ‘from dagš-’. He deduces the meaning from the Tibetan, of which he writes: ‘Tib. sman-gyi khu-ba du-nas (hdu “combine”; 1. 3 du-bar byaho = niśāña-)’. It is not clear, however, why Bailey translates dīṣḍa as ‘is to be poured in’ in his rendering of the passage quoted, as if dīṣḍa were a participle of necessity. The rendering given is misleading for a second reason also, jṣą̄ñāñä daṃdä khu is a common phrase in medical texts and means ‘it is to be boiled until’ or ‘it is to be boiled so much that’. Bailey’s rendering disregards khu and the general usage of the phrase.[emmerick, Ⅱ , p.59]

[DKS] ‘grasping’
[SVK] ‘deception’ [not ‘grasping’] [Emmerick, III, p. 79]
As the line division of Mañj 40 KBT 114—115 indicates, Bailey had not recognised here a word drauna at the time of editing KBT. It is obscured by the use of punctuation in the middle of the word at its first occurrence: drau: na. However, such punctuation is found in the middle of a word elsewhere in Mañj as at 62 KBT 116 dīragā:ra ‘evil-doing’. At its second occurrence it is obscured by the fact that drrau and na are not only separated by being on different lines but by the fact that a deleted syllable precedes na. However, a deleted syllable often occurs in the middle of a word in this manuscript e. g. āśa’ 30, yadrraḍä31, udvīya 37, dasau 61, etc. The passage in which drauna occurs twice was discussed by me in some detail in Asia Major, XVI.1—2, 1971, 63—7. The context was shown to contain a reference to the four deceptions (Buddhist Sanskrit viparyāsa1): ‘the mistake of thinking the impermanent to be permanent, the impersonal to be personal, the impure to be pure, unhappiness to be happiness’. Bailey wishes to understand tcahau-padya jsīrja-hanāsa as ‘the grasp of deceit (= BS śāṭhya-grāha-) is fourfold’. Against this stands the fact that hanāsa is elsewhere absent: tcahau-padya jsīrrjau Mañj 57 KBT 115 and tcahau-padya jsarjau Mañj 316 KBT 129, and simply jsīrjai tcahaure Mañj 66 KBT 116.
uysānā hīvī drauna is understood by Bailey to mean ‘through the grasping of the self (= BS ātman- for ātma-bhāva- “body”)’, but in fact it means ‘by the deception of the self’, that is, by mistakenly believing that the selfless (anātman) is self (ātman). [Emmerick, I, p. 58]

[DKS] ‘smear’
[SVK] Bailey interprets dvā̜ñä in Si 23.17 (137r5 KT 1.74) as ‘it must be besmeared’. He wishes to separate dva- ‘smear’ from dvya- ‘to beat’. The meaning of dvā̜ñä in Si 20.13 (126v5 KT 1.58) is not in doubt. It corresponds closely to Sanskrit tädana- and Tibetan rdeg-pa (see Bailey s. v. dvya-). What reason is there for separating dvā̜ñä in Si 23.17 from dvā̜ñä in Si 20.13 ? The absence of -y- is hardly significant. The -y- may be secondary in any case (see SGS 44 s. v. *dav-), Even if it is not second_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x005f_x001f_ary, dvā̜ñä could easily have been simplified to dvyā̜ñä, In Ch ii.002 it could well be a defective writing of dvyā̜ñä since such defective spellings abound in that manuscript.
Si 23.17 concerns the well-known śata-dhauta-ghṛta, Its preparation is not explained in the Sanskrit text, but the Tibetan and Khotanese versions have more detail. Bailey quotes only part of the corresponding Tibetan, which has: yaṅ-na mar gźu-źiṅ hkhyag-tu bcug-pa de-lta-bur lan brgyahi bar-du byas-te rul-bar gyur-pahi naṅ-du śiṅ-mṅar-gyi phye-ma śas cher blug-ste sbyar-bas bsku-bar byaho ‘alternatively (vā), one must beat (dhautaṃ) ghee (sarpir) and make it congeal, and making it like that a hundred (śata-) times, when it has become rancid, one must pour into it in large quantity (-utkaṭam) the powder from liquorice (yaṣṭi- madhu-), and smear it (over the patient) (lepanaṃ)。
It looks as though the Tibetan rendering provides an interpretation of dhauta- as ‘beaten’. It is clear that the Khotanese follows the Tibetan in this interpretation and that dvā̜ñä ‘to be beaten’ corresponds to Tibetan gźu-ba ‘to strike, to lash’ (Jäschke). gźu-ba is explained as brgyab-pa (‘to beat, strike’) by Sumatiratna.
śata-dhauta-ghṛta in Vāgbhaṭa, Ah., Ci, 18.13 is correctly rendered in Tibetan by lan brgyar bkrus-pahi mar (Peking 196b4) ‘ghee that has been washed a hundred times’. It is washed with cold water (see VŚS s. v. śata-dhauta-ghrtam; Śrīkaṇṭhadatta on Vṛ 19.1). It is no doubt beaten up with the cold water rather than ‘besmeared’ with it. [Emmerik, I, 59]

[DKS] ‘nothingness(P)’
[SVK] In Diet. s.v. naṃñä Bailey quotes from P 2026 #99 sumīrä śaśvāṃ naṃñä ttrāyi hatcä tcauryau dvīpyau, which he translates ‘Sumeru (mountain) (and) the mustard seed he carries away to nothingness to_x001F_gether with the four continents’. His word naṃñä, invented exclusively for this passage, he explains as deriving ‘from na- “not”, with -ṃña-.
The interpretation Bailey proposes for this passage does not agree with Buddhist teaching elsewhere. The correct interpretation was already given by me in JRAS, 1967, 25: sumīrä śaśvā̜nąñä ttrāyi hatcä tcauryau dvīpyau ‘he will deliver Sumeru into the grain of mustard together with the four dvīpas’ With this compare the similar formulation in Ch 1.0021b, a #38-39 KBT 151: sumīra garä pūsą. ttrāyau śaśvāṃ myā̜ñä bīśī hā baiśnä hatsa tcauryā dvīpyau ‘I will completely deliver Mount Sumeru into the middle of a grain of mustard, all of it utterly, together with the four dvīpas’ The loc. sg. śaśvā̜nñä from śśaśvāna- ‘mustard grain’ is like padānaña loc. sg. from padāna- ‘vessel’ (SGS 262). [Emmerick, III, p.79]

[DKS] ‘to burst’
[SVK] In this entry, Bailey lumps together the three verbs listed in SGS 55 as * nirǔj- ‘to burst; disappear’ ‹ *ni-ruj-ya-; *nirus- ‘to burst’ ‹ *ni- ruxsa-; nirūj- ‘to break open’ ‹ *ni-raujaya- (thus Emmerick). What strikes one here is the coexistence of two different, but apparently (partly) synonymous intransitive/passive formations from one and the same root: with -ya- and -sa-. As far as I can see'that is the case with no other verb in Khotanese. Moreover, *nirǔj- forms a secondary causative *nirujāñ- differing in meaning from the simple nirūj-. Close examination of the use of these verbs, however, reveals that only nirūj- and *nirus- belong together as transitive and intransitive respectively, meaning ‘to open /be opened forcefully; to break / be broken open’ (not however ‘to break / be broken’ alone), whereas *nirǔj- means ‘to be destroyed, removed’ rendering Skt. nirudhya- ‘to be stopped, cease; to be suppres_x001F_sed, destroyed’, etc. In fact, *nirǔj- is a loanword from Indian, Skt. nirudhya-, Pali nirujjha-, Gandhari Praktrit nirujadi (Brough p. 302). It is one of the numerous loanwords which do not make their appearance till in Late Khotanese.[Skjsærvø, II, p.65]

[DKS] ‘expel, shake off’
[SVK] To the forms listed in the entry a hitherto unrecognized 1 sg. pres, form naṣphaścū is to be added.
The word occurs in Or. 8212.162.149 KT 2.9. Bailey read naṣkaścū with fn.4 on KT 2.9 ‘Unusual shape of ṣka’. In Saka Documents Text Volume, London 1968, 28, Bailey translated it ‘a register’ without explanation. The way the scribe of Or. 8212.162.125 ff. KT 2.8—10 (facsimile in Saka Documents I, London 1960, plates XII—XIII) writes the akṣara pha is that, after making a loop, he does not stop at the horizontal stroke, but goes through it. See e.g. pha in line 152 (the fourth akṣara from the left). The elements of the ligature ṣpha are recognizable.
The context in which this word occurs follows a passage in which the Linggong accuses those men who did not go to China (although they said they would): Or. 8212.162.148—149 tta ttau hvai sa ttu-v-ā vāsta hūryara ‘He ( = the Linggong) said to us as follows: “Give the clothing to them” ’, 149 u nai hvaḍādū ‘And we did not give it’, 149 u tta ttau hvai sa vañau sa naṣphaścū ‘And he said to us as follows: “Now I shall just (the second sa = saṃ) expel them3”’. In this conversation, we/us is the Khotanese envoys, among whom is the author of this report.Kumamoto, II, p.71
