[DKS] ‘part, portion, amount, period (of time)’
[SVK] ‘Sid. 138rl habistä nasą, “in contracted amount”, Tib. mdor-na “in short”’ (Bailey, Dict.).
habistä nasą, in Si 23.25 should be divided and read habistäna saṃ. The instr.-abl. sg. is used adverbially elsewhere e. g. ṣi’buri hve śāstārä haṃbi’stäna sūtträ (P 2782.57 KT 3.61 = id. P 2029.18 KT 3.55) trans_x001F_lated by Bailey ‘This great teacher taught the sūtra concisely’ (H. W. Bailey, Sad-dharma-puṇḍarīka-sūtra, the summary in Khotan Saka, Canberra 1971, p. 4). saṃ corresponds here to Tibetan kyaṅ. It similarly corresponds to yaṅ in Si 20.19 26.24, 84, 90. [Emmerick, I, 61]

[DKS] ‘checked(?)’
[SVK] ‘Sid. 133v5 cedāma nasta ... “thought checked”’ (Bailey, Diet.)
With this compare Bailey, KT 6.134: ‘Sid. 133v5 cedāma nastä means thought ceased, Tib. sems-pa daṅ has a lacuna.’
The assumption of a lacuna in the Tibetan version is quite gratuitous and is not repeated in the Dict., where the phrase cedāma nastä is inter_x001F_preted in more or less the same way, although two different new etymologies are proposed for nastä.
The idea that ‘thought checked’ or ‘thought ceased’ is totally at variance with what medical texts teach concerning the man with a phlegmatic nature. In Vāgbhaṭa, Śā. 3.96 he is described as buddhyā yuktaḥ ‘mit Einsicht begabt’ and in Śa. 3.101 as gambhīraḥ ‘tief veran- lagt’. The latter is rendered in Tibetan (Pek. 91b4) as blo zab ‘(having) deep thoughts’. It is accordingly more likely that cedąma nastä in Si 22.4 means ‘(his) thought (is) profound’.
As long as this nastä remains isolated, however, it must remain suspect. One can for example suspect that the scribe intended to write *cedą̄mastä ‘thoughtful’ (with the -asta suffix mentioned above s. v. chadrasta) but added na because he thought of cedą̄mana ‘cintāmaṇi’.
On the other hand, there is an unexplained nasta in Old Khotanese. On possible explanations of nasta in Śgs see my edition p. 66. In Dict. s. v. nasta bāgyä ‘root’ a new explanation is proposed. Bailey explains the expression as being literally ‘end-part’. The idea that bāga- ‘part’ is to be sought here seems to have been forgotten or abandoned by Bailey by the time he reached the letter b since nastā bāgyā is listed under bāga ‘root’, not under bāga- ‘part, portion’. This nasta remains obscure to me, but it may be the same nasta ‘deep’ as may be attested in Si 22.4.[Emmerick, I, p.61]

[DKS] ‘are perished’
[SVK] The rendering ‘are perished’ is not convincing as ‘perished’ is sufficient. We cannot have here the ‘base nas- “perish”, passive nasya- with periphrastic āya (?)’. From *nasya- the expected development is to *naśś- as in panaśś- ‘to perish’ from *apa-nas-ya- cf. Avestan apanasiia- (SGS 70).
Bailey seems to have been misled into thinking that nas- is here required because in P 2786.196 KT 2.99 he read hauvą hänasyąvą, which he renders ‘the forces exhausted’ and compared this hänasyqvq with hanaśś- ‘to fail’. However, hä is probably to be read as hā and if not it must in any case be emended to it in the light of the second version of the text in Or. 8212.186.33 KT 2.11, which has ] ra hā naspava. There naspava is a graphic error for *nasyava as noted tentatively by Bailey, KT 2.11 n. 8. That we have here the particle hā is also confirmed by hā hauvä nasyaiyą in P 2786.202—203 KT 2.99 = hā hauva nayseye Or. 8212.186.40 KT 2.11. Incidentally, the above parallels exclude the possibility of dividing the syllables so as to obtain hauvana ‘powerful’ as Bailey does in KT 2.11.
The ending -aiyą/-eye limits the number of possibilities because there are very few verbs conjugated according to my C and D patterns (SGS 177). nasyaiyą/nayseye points to an Old Khotanese 3sg. present middle *niysaiye from *ni-zav- comparable with Old Khotanese buysaiyä from *vi-zav- (SGS 101). nasyaiyą is probably a graphic simplification of *naysyaiyą rather than a mistake for *naysaiyą (cf. nayseye) since the intrusive -y- is likely to be due to the preverb *ni just as Late Khotanese has buysvaiye for Old Khotanese buysaiye with a secondary -v- due to the preverb bu-. For these forms of buysai- see SGS 101.
The past participle nasyąvą probably also stands for *naysyąvą for Old Khotanese *niysuta. Here of course *naysyąvą is 3sg. perfect intransitive feminine. The -ya- will be for an earlier -ä- due to *ni, cf. Late Khotanese jyava Mañj 122KBT 119 = Old Khotanese jäta Z 23.20.
hā hauvä nasyaiyą is thus ‘strength fails’ and hauvą hā nasyąvą ‘strength has failed’, that is, ‘(my) strength is exhausted’.[Emmerick, II, p.71]
[DKS] v.l. pai nā ‘he took the cup(?)’

[DKS] ‘roar, thunder’
[SVK] Read ttārä.
Bailey’s reading of this word as nārä in the Amṛta-prabhadhāram 49 (25b8) KT 5.64 is not correct. Close inspection of the akṣara in question on the photographs in the Hamburg collection reveals that it has none of the characteristics of a nā. Comparison of this akṣara with similar or even nearly identical akṣaras in the same manuscripts furthermore indicates that it cannot be dā, vā or even ntā (in 23b 10 aparānta), and so must be ttā. Cf. (Hamburg photograph nos. in [ ]): ttā(rä) 25b8 [212]; tti 25b7 [212]; ttā(rä) 23b 12 [216]. [Skjsærvø, II, p.73]

[DKS] ‘not’
[SVK] nä, nu, ne, ni ‘them, their’, enclitic (Dict.)
‘From *na- pronoun "that", plur. *nai. IE Pok. 319 e-no-, no-, Av. ana-... 0. Ind. aná-..．nā-nā "variously", Greekvaí “surely", Lat. enim, nam "for".’(Dict.)
This etymology is unsatisfactory, if only because none of the proposed cognates listed by Bailey functions as an enclitic pronoun. In most Iranian languages the third person plural enclitic pronoun is formed from the same stem as its third person singular counterpart. Thus, Old Persian has sg. -šaiy: pl.-šam, continued in Middle Persian by -š: -š’n, where the pl. form results from a thematicized *-šānām. In the case of Sogdian -š(y): -šn， the plural must be derived from *-šǎn̄ā̆m，with secondary shortening of unstressed ā in a polysyllabic ending (cf. pronominal genitive plurals such aswyšnw < *awaišanăm, wyspyšnw < * wispaišănăm). While these languages have generalized the sandhi-forms with š (cf. Av.šē），others have generalized that with h (cf. Av. hē), as exemplified by Bactrian -ηιo : -avo, Choresmian -hi : -na, Parachi -ē: -an. All these forms require the reconstruction of a thematic *-hānām, with secondary shortening to *hănā̆m at least in Choresmian and Parachi.
A similar form is to be expected for the third person plural enclitic pronoun in Khotanese in view of the third person singular -ī, yä < *-hai. Accordingly, Khotanese nu may be derived from *-hănăm (with secondary shortening of both syllables as in the thematic genitive-dative plural ending -änu beside -ānu, cf.SGS267），while the more common spellings nä and ni may show the influence of the other enclitic pronouns, most of which end in -ä < *-ai or *-ah (mä, tä, yä, nä < *-mai, *-tai, *-hai, *-nah).
[Sims-Williams, II, p.74]

[DKS] ‘low’
[SVK] ‘Sid. 138r5 neca hame, BS nimno, Tib. hdug-pa "seated", hence for older neʼsta-ʼ(Bailey, Dict.)
Si 24.2 (138r5 KT 1.76) concerns swelling due to wind. It is charac­teristic of this swelling thatgar mnan-pahi mal śoṅ der hdug-pa‘the place where it is pressed (pīḍanān) remains in that hole (nimno)’. The Derge blockprint hasśoṅ ‘hole’ whereas the Narthang and Peking blockprints have śod ‘lower part’. The variation hardly affects the meaning. However, dermust be read as in Derge, not ṅar as N arthang or dar as Peking, which yield no sense. Bailey, Dict., s. v. buro, reads dar, which he says means‘little’, but there is no evidence for that and even with that meaning no sense is obtained. Bailey gives no rendering of the Tibetan with dar.
It is clear from comparison with the Tibetan version that the corresponding Khotanese cve hā haṃguṣṭa jsa ṇehejīdä u dārą buri va neca hame must mean‘when they press it down (pīḍanān) with the finger and it remains there for a long time in the hole (nimno)’. Thus, it is hame that corresponds to Tibetan hdug-pa, which means‘remains’, and neca corresponds to Tibetan śoṅ der‘in that hole’.
This neca‘hole’ is not isolated. As I pointed out in Asia Major,XV.I, 1969, 116, nicu is to be read for Bailey's ni cu in 144r3 KT 1.86 (edd. 1, 2). It corresponds to Tibetan śoṅ ‘hole’. Si 25.26 (144r3-4 KT1.86) provides a prescription for causing a hole to be filled that has arisen after a wound has healed. The Tibetan begins: rma sos-pahi mal śoṅ-du gyur-pa-la ni‘If the place where the wound has healed has become a hole’. After the prescribed treatment slar gaṅ-bar hgyur-ro‘it will become full again (pūraṇam)’. To this the Khotanese corresponds as follows :khu kaṃmä jatte u nicu va hamāte ..．ṣi’ nica haṃbaḍa hameIf the wound heals and a hole should occur there ... the hole will be
filled.’ Thus, nicuand nicamean ‘hole’ and correspond to Tibetan śoṅ‘hole’.
There seems to me to be no reason to look for a connection with ne’sta-‘seated’ for this neca, nicu, nica‘hole’. Such a connection would in any case involve a phonological difficulty since it is unlikely that the subscript hook should be absent in all three places. I would suggest therefore that the word is connected rather with nata-，näta-‘deep’ .
Note that Bailey's entry nica‘again (?)’ has been abolished by the above analysis.
[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.63]

[DKS] ‘flame(?)’
[SVK] ‘flame’
The fragment containing this word is from Suv: [Suv 4.12] nvāska­masi‘as much as a nvāska’translates Skt vyāma ‘a fathom’ (Nobel p. 49).
Emmerick suggests that nvāska-must be derived from *ni-bāzuka-, comparing Av. vībāzu-‘fathom’. As for the development of -z-ka〉-ska­rather than -ysga-as in baysga-‘thick, deep; many’ < *bazaka-he points out that all the known examples of this development contain -z-ka­­-preceded by a short vowel , and that the development after a long vowel may have been different. This Emmerick thinks could also be the reason for the unvoiced -st- < -js-t- in pasūste instead of *pasūysde < pasūjs- ­(SGS78).
It should be pointed out however that the prefix ni- is an unexpected substitute for vi-which contains an important semantic factor of ‘fa­thom’, the width of the outstretched arms.
[Skjærvø,Ⅰ, p.67]

[DKS] ‘region’
[SVK] ‘region’ (Dict.)
pais reduced from pata, which represents the ‘older’ form as stated by Bailey. However, Bailey's assumption that patarepresents a feminine stem *patā-is arbitrary. Moreover, his proposed derivation ‘from .. . base pat- "be extended", beside paθ-, Av. paθana-’, which he first made known in BSOAS, XXX.l, 1967, 102, is entirely without support.
pa(ta) is several times attested in the phrase rravyi pata‘southern region’, which in Vajr 12a2 KT 3.22 renders Sanskrit dakṣiṇa-...dig-‘southern direction’. This recalls at once Sanskrit dakṣiṇāpatha-‘the southern region, Deccan’ and one is tempted to ask whether patacannot represent Sanskrit patha.
There is another word pata- in Khotanese. It is a loan from Sanskrit pada-‘stanza’ via North West Prakrit (see Acta lranica, 21, 1981, 186- 187). Thus pata-is the regular Khotanese representation of North West Prakrit pada-. Now in North West Prakrit we find such spellings as yadabeside yatha for Sanskrit yathā (J. Brough, The Gāndhārī Dharmapada, OUP 1962, §49 p. 100) and we may assume therefore that Khotanese pata-‘region’ is borrowed from a North West Prakrit *padaderiving from Sanskrit patha. That this actually is the case is proved by Khotanese dakṣäṇāvatä Z 24.396, where the expected -t- is found for the -th- of Sanskritdakṣiṇāpatha. It remains to be seen whether traces of North West Prakrit *pada‘region’can be found in the modern Nuristani languages.
[Emmerick, II, p.76]

[DKS] ‘flesh’
[SVK] ‘flesh’
According to Baileysya pa’ in Si 3.20.15 (l7vl KT1.26) means ‘flesh of goose’. In fact, pa’‘flesh’ does not exist . pa’is merely a scribal error forpa’jsä‘very’. The passage reads: ttekyāṃ haṃdrre-vya sya*pa’jsä vrriṣaṇīya ‘Among those (teṣāṃ) (water birds, flesh of) the goose (haṃso) is very virilific (vṛṣyatamas in MSS BCD).’
*pa’jsä vrriṣaṇīyacorresponds exactly to Sanskrit vṛṣyatamas. It can be further corroborated by comparing pa’jsä vrriṣaṇīya in Si 2.9 (11v2 KT 1.16), which corresponds to Sanskrit ati-vṛṣyo (in MS A).

[DKS] ‘defeat, overthrow’
[SVK] ‘defeat, overthrow’ This abstract noun occurs in Suv [6.1.62] (29v5 KT 5.107), where it glosses nyauṣca‘defeat’. The Sanskrit differs.
The verb is found in Suv [6.4.56], which has *patājä[u] purrä‘you will overcome and defeat’ corresponding to Skt. parājayiṣyati. In H vii.150.13#v3 KT 5.82 Bailey reads only xx xx -ä, but close scrutiny of the manuscript enabled me to read *patājä[u]purrä.
patāj- should be derived from *apa-tāčai̯a-‘make run back’ rather than from *pati-tāčai̯a- as suggested by Bailey, as we would in that case expect -tt-, cf. pattarrā-‘drink’< *pati-tṛšnā(see above s. v. pattarrā-).
Cf. also byāj-‘to dissolve’< *u̯i-tācai̯a- and for pa-< *apa-, cf. SGS235.
The past participle may be seen in LKh. pattīya-, which occurs twice in P 2741 (KT 2.91-92), but the contexts are not clear enough to be certain: line 100 khu durbikṣä u āphāji pattīye‘when hunger and chaos were *overcome’ (?) and lines 122-123 cū jsāṃṃ mistāṃ hvąṇḍā ttyāṃ hīya jsāṃ hauva ja u ñāttarāṃ hīya hīya hauva pattīya‘if(?) the power of those great men was destroyed and the power of the lesser ones *overcome’(?).
From other Iranian languages we may compare Man. MPers. abdaxt‘to escape’and abdāz-, abdāxt‘to set free.’ For the variation pa-/ab- cf.,e.g., Inscr. MPers. pāyēs = Parth. pad(d)ēs＝Man. MPers. payēs = Parth.abdēs．
[Skjærvø, III, p.84]

[DKS] ‘food’
[SVK] pattarrā-‘drink’[not‘food’ as Dict. 204b]
According to Skjærvø,‘[t]he exact meaning of pattarrā- has not yet
been definitively established’ (Suv 3.121), though he consistently translates the Suv occurrences of the word by‘drink, beverage’. In fact, in four of the passages for which bilingual evidence is available pattarrā- is clearly used in correspondence with Skt. pāna- and pānīya-‘drink, beverage’;
moreover, in KV the meaning‘drink’is confirmed by the fact that
pattarrā- is a remedy against ttarra-‘thirst’
[Maggi,III, p.39]

[DKS] ‘covering (?)’
[SVK] patisu‘in autumn’ 1.68
On the meaning and attestations of this word see Skjærvø, BSOAS,XLIV.3 1981, 463-465. The form of the word is still problematic. According to D. Hitch, IIJ，33.3, 1990, 197, the form cannot be explained from a stem *pataśa- with the ending-u by synchronic rules. Another possibility would then be to derive it from an Old Iranian adverbial form *ozi̯ammeaning‘verging upon winter.’Thus, the -u would not be an ending,
but part of the original stem.
[Skjærvø,III, p.85]

[DKS] ‘of messengers’
[SVK] an unknown commodity [not ‘of messengers’ as Dict. 225a]
The word pa’sīñä is found on a wooden stick in the I.O.L. W[ood] 3 in an unintelligible context: (al) khattīnai svirrnadattä pu’sū pa’sīñä 7 cha ura -ūṃ (2) x ñau saṃ kūsa ‘I Khattīnai ask after Svirmadatta (?). pa’sīñä 7 *chāsand ...a kūsa (?).’ It occurs also in a long letter from Mazar Tagh (M.T. a. 1.0033 #4-5 KT2.71 SDTV1.73): pasām āstaṃna stūra kai ’tta khvaṃ tta na panāśari ci tta aśnesalą̄ña pa’sīña drą̄ma ṣṭāri yāṃ kum y- hauryari khu na hvā’re ‘Look after the sheep and the other domestic animals so that none are lost for me. Whatever *such pa’sīñas there are from Aśnesala (?), give them to Yāṃ Kuṃ Y-(?) so that they do not *dry up.
These passages seem to rule out Emmerick’s suggestion in SDTV3.153 that the pa’sīña- might be ‘water holes for sheep.’ Hides, of course, might dry up and become useless, but other possibilities no doubt exist.
[Skjærvø,III, p.89]

[DKS] ‘lost, ceased’
[SVK] This unique word has been invented on the strength of a single Late Khotanese passage only, P 2026.56—57 KT 3.50. In fact, pā is a Late Khotanese form of pātcu‘next, then’. It often occurs in enclitic position following a pronoun but may be postponed if other particles occur as here.
The passage has been misunderstood by Bailey. For the idea behind it, compare Z 4.93-6 and 9.14—16.
ṣa’bvauma cu paysaida ṣa’ rā jsāna bvāma pā rusta
varā drą̄ma na bīde sa khu dai āca pasūśte 43
‘This bodhi, when one recognises (by it the ultimate reality, paramārtha)- this bodhi is indeed then lost. No such (thing) is found there just as a flame of fire burns.’
As the passages in Z show, what is meant is that bodhi does not exist objectively, it is just a parikalpa, a notion, which disappears when by it the ultimate reality is recognised. It is like the lye which when it has cleaned the garment itself dissolves or the fire which burns up the fire grate.
For āca‘flame’, not‘water’as Bailey, see s. v. āca‘in water’.
[Emmerick, I, 70-71]
[DKS] inst. sing. V 174 3a4; b13, see s.v. pāra ‘a measure’.

[DKS] ‘ask’, participle brasta-
[SVK] Bailey’s translation of braṣṭäñe jsa aysu T asked’ (last two lines of p. 245) can only have been intended to tease students of Khotanese. The passage from Suv [Suv 16.24] runs as follows:[...] *vījye (Leumann for vījyo) braṣṭäñe jsa aysu biśśu ve ..., Skt yena dhātu-kauśalyena paripṛṣtenāhaṃ sarvatra ... upasaṃkramiṣyāmi ‘with the skill in the elements (which I) asked about, I shall go everywhere’ (Nobel p. 176). Thus braṣṭäñe jsa is an adjectival past participle qualifying the preceding word and aysu goes with what follows, braṣṭāñe jsa aysu is therefore not an inverted passive (agential) construction expressing past tense as Bailey’s translation might lead one to think. *vījye braṣṭāñe jsa means ‘with the asked-about science’. [Skjsærvø, I, p.75]

[DKS] ‘at once, swiftly’ dyadic with thyau ‘at once’ and raysga vī ‘swiftly’
[SVK] No bilingual evidence has yet been found to settle the precise meaning of puṣṣo. The meaning given in the Diet, by Bailey marks a return to the meaning given by S. Konow in Saka Studies, Oslo 1932, 173: ‘puṣṣo, at once, immediately, M 109 etc., -ṣṣa, -ṣa N 7642, 1588, V’. Subsequently Konow appears to have changed his mind concerning the meaning of puṣṣo since in his Khotansakische Grammatik, Leipzig 1941, 118 he has: ‘puṣṣo wieder, gänzlich’ and in his Primer of Khotanese Saka, Oslo 1949, 113, we find: ‘puṣṣo, altogether, wholly, again’. [Emmerick, II, p.91]

[DKS] ‘love, friendliness’
[SVK] Bailey explains this hapax as ‘from frīna- (or frīvana-) with dialectal or archaic fr- kept’. In fact all three words beginning with phrr- that are listed in the Dict., are loanwords from Tibetan. For phrrūmä ‘thickened milk’ from Tibetan phrum see below s. v. phrramaina was correctly identified by Bailey as representing Tibetan phra-men although he wishes to regard phra-men as borrowed from Iranian. The Tibetan phra-men cannot be from Khotanese because no Khotanese word of Iranian origin has phrr-. Old Iranian *fr- develops regularly to Khotanese br- as in bria- ‘beloved’, cf. Avestan friia-, Old Indian priyá-.
According to Bailey phrrīnä ‘parallels nāśa “tenderness”’, but there is no guarantee that nāśa is parallel with phrrīnä in the sense of being synonymous with it: the lovers can send more than one thing to one another. In any case the reading of the first akṣara of nāśa does not seem to me to be established beyond doubt.
phrrīnä is clearly a loanword from Tibetan (h)phrin ‘message’. śūjäñāṣṭä phrrīnä paśīdä in P 2895.28 KT 3.41 means ‘they send messages to one another’, not as Bailey renders ‘they give out mutual love’. -āṣṭä is the directional suffix ‘towards’ and paś- means ‘to send’, paś- is used with haḍa ‘messengers’ in P 2790.112 KT 2.114 haḍa paśarä ‘send messengers’.
See Die Sprache, 29, 1983.
[Emmerick, Ⅰ, p.81]

[DKS] ‘binding’
[SVK] In Sgh 83r6 KT 5.341 Bailey reads bando for Konow’s ban[d]o and cites it in Dict. 269a as his first example for baṃda- ‘binding’. But in fact, inspection of the manuscript in the India Office Library, London, revealed no trace of a subscript -d- in this word. Since Khotanese has a word banaa- ‘prisoner’, which can easily be derived from bana- ‘prison’ there does not seem to be any reason for emending the manuscript reading, and we should read the Sgh passage: bano kaṣṭumä rruīya ‘I fell into/was bound in the royal prison’. See also above on jjaṣṭumä ‘I came’.

[DKS] ‘protruding’
[SVK] borṣai occurs only in Si 25.33 (144v5 KT 1.86). Bailey renders hatcastä u borṣai-vī hvīḍaas ‘food for fracture and protrusion’. He explains borṣai-vī as ‘having protruding parts’, hatcastä is literally ‘broken’ and is so explained by Bailey s. v. hatcañ- ‘to break’. It is no doubt to be understood as meaning ‘broken (bone)’ since this concept is in the context. In fact, Si 25.32 has bhinnāsthi- ‘broken bone’, which is rendered in the Khotanese version by āstai hatcyą̄ve. It is misleading to quote here, as Bailey does, the Sanskrit of Si 25.32 beside the Khotan­ese and Tibetan of Si 25.33, but it is nevertheless likely that the broken bone and dislocated joint of Si 25.32 are intended also in Si 25.33. That being so, the ‘protrusion’ expressed by Tibetan bur-ba is likely to be protrusion resulting from dislocation.
[Emmerick; I, p.95]

[SVK] byarivā is to be read bvari vā. The akṣara bva is found at the end of the line and only half of it remains. The subscript -v- has a sharp edge to the left but sharp-edged varieties of subscript -v- are attested elsewhere also in cursive script. The bva does not in any case resemble by in byihi’ in line 40. The passage in question is: cū bvari vā ysathvā jsāna ttaradara bīśā’ prraeina * aysmūna yuḍi ttyi karma biśa vasasīdū u jāra (Ch 0048.40—41 KBT 73) ‘However much he may have done in (his) births on account of (his) body (and) tongue (or) due to (his) mind, all his karmas will become pure and disappear.’ Correct accordingly Bailey’s rendering in Buddhist studies in honour of I. B. Horner, ed. L. Cousins et al., Dordrecht 1974, p. 17. cū bvari vā is a LKh. continuation of OKh. cu buro vātcu (Z 12.7).
[Emmerick; II, p.114]

[DKS] ‘extend’
[SVK] In the Dict, this item occurs out of alphabetical order following byāñä ‘to be produced, made, divided’ q. v. The word occurs only in Avdh 20v3—4 KT3.11: vaña tvā haṭhṭha u ttä mista prraṇihāna byāñą huṣṣāñu bihīśų, ‘now make increase, make grow, expand this truth and these great vows’, byāñą, huṣṣāñu, and bihīśų, are all causatives meaning ‘make increase’, byāñąis 2 sg. imperative from by-āñ-, which is formed by the addition of the secondary causative suffix -āñ- (on which see SGS185) to the present stem by- ‘to increase’ (on which see byāñä below). The formation is paralleled by the accompanying word huṣṣāñ- ‘to make grow’, causative from huṣṣ- ‘to grow’. Bailey’s etymology ‘from *vitānaya- “to extend”’ resulted from his failure to recognise by- ‘to increase’.
[Emmerick; I, p.98]

[DKS] ‘beloved’
[SVK] ‘beloved’
In the Suv passage quoted by Bailey (SuvK. 67v2 KT 5.118), for Bailey's manävä we must read ttagatä. The word is rubbed but legible.The passage is as follows: [Suv 13.2] ṣä härä arthä ttagatä brī x1 vä，Skt tad vastu priyaṃ manäpaṃ(Nobel p. 146). We see that Skt vastuhas been rendered triadically in the Khotanese, and that for Skt priyaṃwe have the expected brī‘dear’. The Khotanese word corresponding to Skt manäpaṃapparently contains only two syllables, but even close scrutiny of the photograph of the manuscript has not revealed the correct reading. Possibly one should readma(nā)vä, i. e. with omitted nā-akṣara, but that is conjectural. At any rate the reading brītañä is wholly unwarranted.
[Skjærvø,I, p.100]

[DKS] ‘beloved’
[SVK] brīyanda occurs first in V. S. Vorob’ev-Desjatovskij and M. I.Vorob’eva-Desjatovskaja, Skazanie o Bhadre (novye listy sakskoj rukopisi ‘E’), Moscow 1965, p. 37. There it was explained (p. 84) as nom. singular fem. of a present participle. In BSOAS, XXX.l, 1967, 85 I pointed out that two words are involved: brī and yanda. brī is the regular form for the accusative singular masculine of bria-. yanda is 3 singular injunctive,here used, as commonly, in a hypothetical relative clause.
ṣa ju māta näśtä kye pūru śśau-ysātu tterä brī yanda
crrāmu tvī balysa hamaṅgu biśśä sarvasatva uysnora (Z 2.180)
‘The mother does not exist who feels (lit. makes) her only-born son as beloved as are all beings equally to you, Buddha.’
With this can be compared Z 11.6:avachauda mulysdä hamaṃgga kyai ne brī yande aysmūna
hamaṃggai haṃ vite mulysdä kho rro ttu väte cī brī yande
‘Compassion is unhindered, equal. Compassion is always equal for one who does not have love in his mind for one as also towards him when he does have love for one.’
Bailey has here without justification resuscitated brīyanda apparently for Z 2.180 only. He renders ṣa ju māta näśta kye pūru śśau-ysātu tterä brīyanda as ‘this mother is not who holds the only-born son so dear’. His ‘holds’ is apparently represented by a‘suffix -vant-, with -a < -u’ added to brīyā‘love’. Everywhere else the suffix takes the form -aunda e.g. puñaunda- ‘meritorious’, virśonda- ‘heroic’, bu' jsauda-‘virtuous’ (see Dresden, JS, p. 419). The suffix of brīyanda must also govern the accusative pūru !
[Emmerick,I, p.100-101]

[DKS] ‘made’
[SVK] ‘made’ （Dict. 374a)
In BSOAS, XLIV.3, 1981, 447-448 and Studies 2.126-127 Emmerick suggests that vadanda- ‘made’ may have been created by reanalysis of the negative form a-vadanda- ‘not made’, which really derives from privative a- + padanda- ‘made’ with the usual development of intervocalic -p-to -v-. While this explanation is certainly possible, it is worth pointing out that the older derivation of vadanda- from *awa-dam- (thus Dict.) receives support from the recently discovered Christian Sogdian compound zprt-’wd’my ‘making pure’ (translating Syriac mḥllnyt ‘cleanser’ or mqdšnyt ‘sanctifier’); see BSOAS, LVIII.1, 1955, 59.[Sims-Williams]
[Sims-Williams,III, p.135]

[DKS] ‘court, courtyard’
[SVK] In BSOAS, XLVIII. 1, 1985, 60—73, I have shown that these two words are one and the same and signify ‘door, (palace) gate’, possibly ‘(royal) court’, but not ‘courtyard’.
Khot. vara- is obviously from Old Iranian *dwar- (with later thematicization) and exhibits the same development of *dw › v that we find in Tumshuqese vitana ‘a second time’ (Karmavācanā 2 and 8)1 from *dwita~. The corresponding Khot. form śäta- (i.e. /źeda-/) ‘second’ has a diverging development of *dw-: here it coalesces with Old Iranian *dźw-from Indo-European *ĝhw-, see Emmerick in: Monumentum Georg Morgenstierne, I, 199 ( = Acta iranica, 21, Leiden 1981).
The use of the word for ‘door’ to signify ‘gate, palace gate’ is found in Old Persian (DB. 2. 75, 89 f.), Middle Persian (dar, heterogram BBA) and Parthian (bar, heterogram TROA), and in Sogdian (Vessantara Jātaka 80).
For other Khot. words containing old *dw- (or *θw-), see on vāj- ‘hold’, vāñ- ‘to toss’ and uysvāñätä ‘tosses up’, vāna- ‘dwelling place’
[Skjærvø,II, p.125]

[DKS] ‘door (?)’
[SVK] In BSOAS, XLVIII. 1, 1985, 60—73, I have shown that these two words are one and the same and signify ‘door, (palace) gate’, possibly ‘(royal) court’, but not ‘courtyard’.
Khot. vara- is obviously from Old Iranian *dwar- (with later thematicization) and exhibits the same development of *dw › v that we find in Tumshuqese vitana ‘a second time’ (Karmavācanā 2 and 8)1 from *dwita~. The corresponding Khot. form śäta- (i.e. /źeda-/) ‘second’ has a diverging development of *dw-: here it coalesces with Old Iranian *dźw-from Indo-European *ĝhw-, see Emmerick in: Monumentum Georg Morgenstierne, I, 199 ( = Acta iranica, 21, Leiden 1981).
The use of the word for ‘door’ to signify ‘gate, palace gate’ is found in Old Persian (DB. 2. 75, 89 f.), Middle Persian (dar, heterogram BBA) and Parthian (bar, heterogram TROA), and in Sogdian (Vessantara Jātaka 80).
For other Khot. words containing old *dw- (or *θw-), see on vāj- ‘hold’, vāñ- ‘to toss’ and uysvāñätä ‘tosses up’, vāna- ‘dwelling place’
[Skjærvø,II, p.125]

[DKS] ‘shoulder’
[SVK] sāmalā hiye re ‘the vein of the shoulder’ in Si 21.5 (128v5 KT 1.60) does not correspond to the meaningless ‘BS saṃsthä-sirā- but to aṃsa- sthā sirā ‘the vein on the shoulder’ as pointed out in BSOAS,XXXIV.l, 1971, 103-104 and XXXVII.3, 1974, 650. [Emmerick, I, 121]
In fact, the correct rendering should be ‘the veins of the shoulders’. The only other occurrence of the word known to me is that listed by Bailey in Dict. s.v. sāmalā ‘shoulder’. In P 2893 #248-249 we find paijvā bąñā̜ñä audä svā̜milau vī bure, which I take to mean ‘to be bound from the breasts as far as to the shoulders’, paijvā being locative of the source of motion, for which see Emmerick, ‘Syntax of the cases’, 33. Here svā̜milau can only be plural, which makes it clear that sāmalā in Si 21.5 is likewise plural. [Emmerick, III, 153]
[DKS] ‘month, 2nd month of the end of spring ( = 4th spring month)’

[DKS] ‘tongue-sharpened, eloquent’
[SVK] Bailey has extracted this ‘word’ from Si 20.11 (126v3 KT 1.56): ttye nā̜ma si biátä padimākä nā̜ma ‘its name is the so-called “eloquent- maker”’ (= Sanskrit etat sārasvataṃ nāma, Tibetan miṅ ni Ice bde-bar byed-pa zhes bya-ste). Here si is not part of the name but is the Khotanese word that functions like Sanskrit iti except that it directly precedes the word or words being quoted. The names of medicinal preparations and of diseases are regularly preceded in Si by the formula ttye nā̜ma si. Thus, Si 13.41 (103r3—4 KT 1.38) has: ttye nā̜ma si, oṣṭagrīvakā u hvaṃno vī ūla-gīsārä *nā̜ma ‘its name is the so-called “uṣṭragrīvaka” and in Khotanese “camel-neck” by name’. See MSS, 40, 1981, 32. [Emmerick, I, 121]

[DKS] ‘bad (?)’
[SVK] This sūrai was invented by Bailey on the basis of two passages: Mañj 13 KBT 113 and Mañj 66 KBT 116. In fact, sūrai is just the normal word for ‘clean, pure’: see Dict. s. v. suraa- ‘clean’. [Emmerick, I, p.121]

[DKS] ‘distinguished, famed (?)’
[SVK] This is rather a noun ‘fame’ and is a loanword from Sanskrit suṣṭuti ‘good praise’. It is attested in two passages only, haraysdai dīśi’vī sūṣṭa jasta-kṣīrvā bvari (Ch 0048.38—39 KBT 73) ‘his fame will extend in (all) directions as far as the realms of the gods.’ dyena cha bu’jsā suṣṭya. ttyau āysya pharāka kalpa. ‘with (fine) appearance, (good) complexion, virtues, fame—adorned with those for many aeons’ in Suv 3.91 (P3513.73r2 KT 1.248) corresponds to Skt. rūpeṇa varṇena yaśena kīrtyā samalaṃkṛtā bhontu aneka-kalpān (ed. J. Nobel p. 42 lines 2—3). Thus suṣṭya corresponds to Skt. kīrtyā ‘fame’. [Emmerick, II, 150]
[DKS] v 262 DR 0233 to read cu rro ja nase nātu īni tätä ne paśīdi ‘whatever shares I may have received, those they do not let go (send?)’. See s.v. nās-.
